author: steveharringtoned
title: the boys of summer
summary:
“Steve,” Wayne echoes. “This is my home. Eddie’s my boy.” And then he ruffles his hair with one large hand, coarse from years of working with them, in an action that reminds Steve of Hopper.

“I’m gonna go down there and get my boy back. You’re gonna be my tour guide.” He holds his hand out for the final gun Steve has stashed, which he gives over reluctantly. He finds Wayne remarkably difficult to argue with—wonders if Eddie found the same. “Tour guides don’t need guns. You point at somethin’, I shoot it. Got it, Steve?”

(Steve knows Eddie’s alive. Wayne’s the only one who believes him. So they team up to save him.)

text:
Summer gathers the remnants of Hawkins’ population in a grip of dry sand and sweltering heat. 

 

Back in the days of Harrington house parties and his empire of underage drinking, the start of summer would act as a ribbon Steve would cut on the party scene in Hawkins. The first party he would host would give way to a shockwave of other, not-as-good but still worthwhile time wasters around the neighborhood, Hawkins’ suburbia lit up with specially-bought disco lights and the familiar red-blues of police cars crawling the streets to sweep up the easiest pickings of the bunch to satisfy angered neighbors. 

 

Today, Steve does not move. Steve lies in bed as humidity licks up his skin like an enthusiastic labrador, trying not to choke as he tilts a cool beer bottle to the dry flesh of his lips. 

 

He doesn’t have plans to plaster his ID down on the counter at the liquor store two towns over to buy it out of cider, beer and the burn of cheap, shitty vodka; no plans to get wasted at the shore of Lover’s Lake while Tommy palms some pretty blonde off on him. His sweat won’t mingle with her’s, he won’t brave the rolls of heat as skin meets skin until the only solution is the lapping waters at their feet.

 

Two, three summers ago, that would’ve been Steve’s routine. Drink, swim, fuck and maybe sleep. Destroy his home for the rush of fumbling teens shouting out his name like he was their pariah, the messiah—pick up the glass shards of his mother’s vase the next morning, scrub the sink free of someone’s drinking limit reached. 

 

Today, Steve only moves from his bed to get another bottle. 

 

He knows Robin is worried, knows she’s roped Nancy in on it too, to the point where Jonathan Byers of all people, back from Cali for good, had knocked on his door to do a welfare check.

 

Steve had sent him on his way with a little baggy of weed he’d bought for the nightmares, bought his silence about the broken furniture and beer bottles that littered the palace floors of castle Harrington. 

 

The next time Jonathan came around, he stayed. The two of them smoked up and drank and kept distance between them to avoid the discomfort of skin sticking to skin, let alone their previous misdemeanors they continued to bury. 

 

High-Jonathan told Steve that he was worried about Will, that his brother kept waking up in cold sweats, dreaming about versions where they lost, where Hawkins was divided up in a flaming disaster as Vecna had wanted.

 

Steve told high-Jonathan that he’d been dreaming about Eddie in the Upside Down, alone, scared and fighting, every night like clockwork since they’d been forced to leave his body there. 

 

High-Jonathan had the nerve to look at him like he was crazy. 

 

He wasn’t the first person Steve had told—as soon as it started, he’d gone to speak to Dustin. 

 

“Are you dreaming about Eddie?” He’d asked, and then Dustin had wailed and collapsed in a heap of grieving teenager in his arms and Steve got his answer. Yes. But not in the way he had. 

 

Dustin had described dreaming about Eddie’s death over and over again, a recurring nightmare. Steve had swallowed his tongue and said that his were the same. 

 

How was he meant to look the kid in the face and say that in all of his dreams, Eddie was alive— and terrified. 



 

 



In the dreams he was always running from something. Typically, Steve would be the one he ran from—though he knew it wasn’t him, Eddie was fleeing from some abomination that had trickled into Hawkins before, now trapped in the dimension it had been birthed from. 

 

Sometimes, Steve was flying in a pack, light and airy. Other times, Steve was on all fours, claws scraping the dirt for grip and the final push to try and catch the prey, catch Eddie. 

 

The worst of times Steve was tall. Too tall, prowling and stalking, desperate, hungry. 

 

Eddie was good at running. Really good. It made Steve wonder why the one time he needed to run, he didn’t. Steve wonders if it was his fault, if by telling him one thing Eddie felt the indignant urge to do the other. 

 

It had made Eddie their only casualty, by the end of things. 

 

Steve had returned, pumped full of bravado and a twinge of unease, Vecna’s body gone from the ashy cutout it had scorched into the dead grass. 

 

(There had been no final chime of the clock. Erica had brought another Walkman, just in case—and Lucas had knocked Jason out cold before Max’s bones had broken. She was safe, though rattled. Lucas was beaten, but did not have to feel the gaping loss of someone he loved.)

 

But outside of the trailer, Dustin was screaming so loud Steve felt his insides die and rot, terrified that he had returned to see the kid he cared for too much in agony, near-death. Then his body had shifted, angled itself towards Steve, and bundled up in shaking arms was a corpse. A ghost of a person they had grown to know, to accept as one of their own. 

 

Eddie was dead. There was no doubt in it—his blood soaked enough of the dying ground to bathe in it, his insides uncomfortably outside. His corpse was so desecrated, practically in two pieces—Steve couldn’t bear to try and carry it back through with them. 

 

Dustin had punched him in the face when Steve forcibly dragged him through the gate in Eddie’s trailer. The shock was more palpable than the pain—because he stood there and took it. Dustin got three, maybe four hits in before Nancy managed to wrangle him away. 

 

It wasn’t like he had a strong arm—but Steve’s nose bled, almost in lieu of tears. Dustin had fought Nancy, had screamed a barrage of insults Steve knew he didn’t really mean, but still stuck, anyway. 

 

This was the kid he’d grown to think of like a brother. The kid who’d called him a monster, who’d blamed him and probably still did when El’s powers had sealed the gates, sealed Eddie’s body in another dimension. 

 

The kid who couldn’t look at him when the police force officially announced an apology for mistakenly naming Eddie as a suspect, clearing his name in death despite the town’s confusion. 

 

The kid who’d let Steve comfort him, told him about his nightmares—but when Steve had driven them both to the cemetery to visit Eddie’s grave, Dustin had made a comment about it being empty. 

 

Because of you, had been implied in the pain of his voice. 

 

It would never be the same between them. Not with Eddie dead, his body never laid to rest in peace. 

 

Dustin was the first of the people Steve cared about that he stopped talking to. Not the last.

 

Robin had been next. 



 

 

 



 

They’d returned to work far too soon, tense and sharp around the edges despite being under the guise that this was meant to be a victory. They’d won. 

 

But Robin would refuse to sort the tapes in the horror section, and Steve would be scared to go out back alone. It was stupid but it was mutual, they shared in the outlandish terror of normalcy and had each other when shit got weird. 

 

So a month after Eddie’s death, Steve told Robin about the dreams. Sat with her in the storage closet and explained each and every one, admitted that he’d begun thinking just maybe —he was alive. 

 

Steve had told her he wanted to go back, somehow. To get him, or his body, at the very least. 

 

Robin didn’t believe him. She wasn’t malicious, but it felt malign, the rejection—she’d chalked Steve’s dreams up to survivor’s guilt, used his distance with Dustin as an explanation and told him that what he was suggesting was insane. 

 

And when Steve got blazing mad, white hot anger lashing out at the one person he’d always expected to have his back through whatever crazy shit was happening—Robin insisted he take the week off. 

 

Gather himself. Go process the grief he’d clearly been putting off, like this was all some big act because he didn’t want to admit how much he cared about Eddie.

 

Steve had taken the week off.

 

And the next. 

 

Then he just never came back to work. 

 

Robin had called, Steve had ignored her. She came round, shouted through the windows until his neighbors had threatened to call the police. She wrangled Nancy to her cause, both of them finding similar results—meaning Steve ignored them, or was passed out in his room gripping the neck of a bottle, dreaming about Eddie running. Eddie alive, though dying. 

 

Then came Jonathan’s welfare checks. A smart idea on Nancy’s behalf, no doubt—Jonathan was relatively harmless. He didn’t care enough about Steve to force him to take care of himself, but would also turn him on his side so he didn’t die in his sleep, or whatever. He was easily bought with weed, and didn’t nag or judge that much when they were both high out of their minds. 

 

He would go back and tell Nancy and Robin what they wanted to hear. Steve would be left alone to dream about Eddie.

 

(The kids had called by, once or twice. Clearly Dustin had told them that Steve wouldn’t come round to see him anymore, not even for Mrs Henderson’s dinners. They’d insisted it was because they wanted to use his pool in the heat, but Steve had opened the door a crack, just a little drunk—sleepy, not much of anything else. Max had taken one look at him and forced them all to leave.)

 

For Max, Steve answered the phone. Max, he left it on the table, sat and listened as she screamed at him for what he was doing, drinking instead of talking to them. Steve weakly tried to explain that it helped him fall asleep for longer—let him try to figure out what was going on with Eddie. 

 

Max had told him that it was nothing to do with Eddie, and was all to do with him throwing away everything good in his life.

 

She didn’t call back after that. 

 

 

 




 

But no matter what anyone said—it wasn’t like that. Steve was drinking out of necessity, it had always helped him stay asleep and that’s what he needed right now. He couldn’t see a full picture of Eddie in a couple of hours, he had to stay under, figure out if this was real or if Steve was a head case. 

 

If he got five hours or more, he could watch Eddie weave and duck in the foliage of the Upside Down, see glimpses of him hiding, sometimes even crying, begging. The first time Steve got eight hours of sleep in months, maybe even years, he heard Eddie’s voice, low, mumbled swears and song lyrics whispered to himself in the dark. 

 

Steve locked his doors, drew his blinds and kept the house dark, pitch-black. Kept himself inebriated, tired and confused so when sleep came, his brain wouldn’t know the time; know any better. 

 

Days or weeks could have passed—Steve wouldn’t know. But when he fell asleep in a bath he’d filled with ice to avoid the close weather keeping him uncomfortably awake, he saw Eddie. Really saw him. 

 

He was covered in grime, head to toe bathed in a mix of blood and dirt and otherworldly substances without a name to them. He was in Steve’s bedroom, the wallpaper from a couple years ago, his varsity jacket still hung up proudly. A trinket of who Steve used to be.

 

Eddie takes the jacket—bundles himself up in it, Harrington spread between his shoulder blades in big, bold letters. 

 

Steve feels his heart clench, something uneasy churning in his gut. A warmth, a tentative fondness. Back then, he’d always wanted Nancy to wear his jacket. It was a possessive sort of thing, which made him smile to think about. She’d hated the idea, of course—the colours were gaudy and she never liked to feel like she was something of Steve’s, though he can’t fault her for it. 

 

Seeing Eddie wear it now, pulling it over marred skin like a shield, a comfort, a piece of Steve to protect him now, though he didn’t before—

 

Steve wakes up to the lights in his house on the fritz, frantic and throbbing like the pulsing walls of his head, a homing beacon, a taunt. They spark and jitter, flickering, their thrum coiling around the drums of Steve’s ears until all he feels is the pounding blood lapping up his better instincts. Stumbling from the bath, he holds the butter-coloured walls of the landing with a damp hand, clothes dripping with cool water; teeth chattering, though for nerves or the cold he’s not sure. 

 

He follows the hysteria of the electrics into his room, where the petal-shaped bulbs in his ceiling burn like cats’ eyes in the headlights of cars thundering up the highway. Bright enough to bring Steve’s hand to shield his face, to urge tears to drip through his lashes, though maybe from shock, drink or simply the ache the glaring lustre the Upside Down beckons burns into his skull. 

 

Steve knows what this means. Remembers the pivotal shift of his life; bystander to fighter. Where he’d leaned up against his car door, eyes as wide as dinner plates, gleaming through the front facing window of the Byers’, Christmas lights singing the tune of death. 

 

This isn’t a coincidence. This isn’t Steve going crazy. 

 

“ Eddie ?” His voice is hoarse, warm with the drink and rough with the strain of his scalding anguish. 

 

The lights falter. Flickering, dimming. 

 

For an awful second, Steve thinks he’s lost him. Wonders if Eddie had heard his voice and fled, or maybe he had, truly, gone insane. If he’s imagined him all along—because of all people to seek help from, why would Eddie pick Steve? Steve, who left his corpse to rot, who trusted him to run, maybe beckoned him to do the opposite just by asking him to save himself. 

 

Bathed in darkness, Steve finds himself on his knees, bile hot and thick in the cavern of his throat, brothing, boiling. The room is spinning, he finds one arm to curve around the pulsing wounds from the bats, eyelashes wet with fat, defiant tears. 

 

Then the decade-old lampshade stuffed in the tightest corner of Steve’s room starts to hum, the gentle hue of its bulb kissing the damp flesh of his face, licking it in stripes of tender light and love. 

 

“Eddie,” Steve’s laughing now, his broken voice marred by sobs and uncontrollable bubbles of relief, a promise, a certainty. He wasn’t crazy—and Eddie wasn’t dead. “Eds, you’re—you’re here, oh, man, you’re really here,” 

 

Taking it into two shaking hands, palms slick with sweat and bath water, Steve cradles the lamp between his knees, presses it up against his chest. It was a substitute—a confirmation, his savior, proof that his gradual descent into unutterable self-destruction was worth something. 

 

The lamp light flickers, almost giggling with him. 

 

“I miss you. I know that’s stupid,” Steve hiccups, suddenly aware of the bottle of tequila he’d hounded down his throat like a firecracker earlier in what he thinks was the afternoon. “I really sorta liked you, man. You were funny and embarrassing and I fucking liked that shit. You—you were a total freak and I think, you—we should’ve been friends. We really should have? Why weren’t we—we should have,” 

 

Drunken nausea swirls in the deepest pit of his stomach, bitter claws scratching at the lining of his throat. The lamp light dims, then glows once, dips again, glows again, for a slightly shorter duration. 

 

It feels a bit like shut up. Steve laughs, and kisses the dusty floral lampshade, giggling through his panting sobs. “I’m sorry. I wasn’t—if I knew you’d be here, I would’ve—I wouldn’t’ve, y’know,” He hiccups again, sending him into another weak spurt of giggles; a final burst of murky water from a dying fountain. 

 

The lamp dims, then glows. Almost a demonstration—a call to attention. 

 

Steve goes quiet, like a child scolded. Hand in the cookie jar, juice spilt on the carpet. 

 

He was always shit at Boy Scouts. Steve hated the stupid fiddly knots, didn’t like getting dirty and wasn’t big on the whole shelter building thing either. But when something saves his life, he typically remembers, even in a mix of tequila and vodka-induced haze. 

 

Morse code. The same piece they’d used in the Wheeler house to communicate with Dustin. 

 

S.O.S.



 

 



Nancy and Jonathan are on a road trip back to California to see Argyle. Steve knows this because of a scrappy note posted through his front door, scraggly and apologetic and entirely his new smoking partner’s handiwork. 

 

This is relevant because Steve just walked the distance to the Wheeler house, half-drunk and entirely high on the adrenaline of being right, the fear of wasting time and losing Eddie all over again. And Steve is scaling her garage roof like he’s done many times before, making sure to keep his feet steady in the wooden paving attached to the brickwork, sucking in breaths and bringing his knees up to his chin until he’s able to bodily shove her window open, tumbling inside on all fours. 

 

Steve hopes that Nancy doesn’t consider Argyle enough of a threat to take her guns with her to California. 

 

She doesn’t—they lie there, hidden behind multiple boxes that pretend to guard shoes but instead case ammo, shelved up to reveal her growing collection. 

 

The sawed shotgun is there, wrapped up in a tawny-coloured dress. Steve slots it on his back, tucking it into the army gear he’d retrieved from the back of his closet as soon as Eddie’s message had dimmed. The Makarov is a few boxes away too, the one lifted from the Russians—Steve has no idea how to use it, decides it can’t be all that hard and stuffs it in his pocket. The Smith & Wesson Model 10 M&P handgun is also at a total loss to Steve, but in his drunken, determined bravado, once again decides it won’t hinder him in the slightest. 

 

He gathers the ammo he can find, stuffs it down the army jacket, and knows that when it comes down to it, he’ll always know how to wield his bat, at the least. 

 

Getting in wasn’t the problem, despite Steve’s struggle with the window, and Karen Wheeler’s new hyacinth. 

 

Getting out meant crawling backwards, trying to balance the shotgun so it didn’t drag his weight diagonally, swearing when his foot missed the latch in the trellis. He ends up sprawled out like a starfish on his back in the Wheeler’s perfectly maintained hedges, groaning as the neck of the gun carves an unhappy indent into his spine. 

 

Mike hovers above him, eyebrows raised in a pinch, arms folded tightly across his chest. He holds himself like he’s always witnessing someone do something truly stupid, judgement scrawled across his face like words carved into stone. He’s what the masses would call a typical teenage boy, despite his superpowered girlfriend and his previously-possessed best friend. Bitter, grumpy, snappy. 

 

Standing over Steve, he looks a perfect mix of all three. 

 

“What the fuck is this? You ignored all of us for months and now you’re… breaking into my house?” There’s an uptight tone to his voice, painfully familiar. The anger pushed his words out in a venomous hiss, quiet enough to be wary of waking his parents yet still dripping with poison. “Are you stealing shit for drug money?”

 

Spluttering, Steve abandons his attempts to hide the obvious weaponry strapped to him in an effort to dissuade this narrative. “I don’t— what? I don’t do drugs, Mike!” His own whispers are slightly messier, though entirely aware that Ted Wheeler waking up to witness this interaction would be an awful, awkward affair. 

 

“Uh, yeah, you do—”

 

“Weed does not count,” Steve hisses, chopping his hands in a firm no motion. “And I can afford weed, I’m not—I’m not stealing shit from your house for money, Mike,”

 

“But you are stealing shit from my house?” Mike juts his chin out, victory gleaming in his catty little eyes. “What the fuck is wrong with you, Steve? Max says you’re like, an alcoholic now.”

 

Raising his eyebrows, Steve goes to deny that allegation, only to be cut off by Mike swiftly grabbing his face, scowling into his eyes. “You’re drunk right now, fucking Christ.”

 

“I’m really not,” Steve insists, slapping prying hands away. 

 

Mike’s face suggests a total disbelief in Steve’s barked argument, but he drops him anyway, scoffing. “You smell like tequila,”

 

“You should not know what that smells like—but I’m not drunk, I was drinking, there’s a difference,” One hand pointing in aggressive gesticulations, Steve entirely foregoes his previous effort to hide the huge shotgun strapped to his back, let alone his nail bat hung on the hook of his side. 

 

Mike notices this time, his indignant scoff lost to his wordless effort to look at Steve like he’s insane. “What the fuck, Steve, are those my sister’s guns? You stole my sister’s guns?” Then he notes the nail bat, groaning with all the force of disdain a teenage boy can have. “You’re going to try and go back to the Upside Down. God, you’re so fucking stupid,”

 

Mouth dry, Steve shakes his head. “No, I’m not.” He’s not sure if he’s denying being stupid or going back to the Upside Down. 

 

“I’m calling Hopper,” Mike spits, starting to storm up his garden path—startling when Steve grabs his elbow.

 

“Do not do that—” His whispers become more like frantic gasps of air, eyes wide and probably wild. “Mike, please,”

 

The boy looks at him again, and clearly Steve must be in a state, because if they were in daylight, he’d be much more sure that there was worry on Mike’s face. Mike tugs his arm out of his grip, holding it against his chest defensively, brow furrowed like Steve was some kind of problem he didn’t quite understand. “Tell me exactly what you’re doing, right now. Or I’ll yell really loud so mom calls the police,” 

 

It feels just a little bit like a compromise. Which is strange—because Mike has never compromised with Steve in his life. It’s all or nothing with him. Front seat, or he won’t get in the car and will tell his mom Steve left him behind. Curly fries to share in the diner, or he’ll go home hungry and say he was starved. 

 

For Steve and Mike, this is revolutionary . Something to shout about, if they weren’t so determined to keep the Wheeler parents asleep. 

 

“Eddie’s alive,” Steve says, voice as firm as steel, as certain as the sun rising in the east. “I saw him in the Upside Down in my dreams,” He pauses, waiting for Mike to mock him—he doesn’t. He just stares, big, dark eyes cold and concerned. “Then he spoke to me through the—the lights, in my house. He did the, the uh, morse code thing, the S.O.S.” 

 

“I know what the S.O.S. signal is, Steve,” Mike says, though there’s not much bite to it. 

 

Steve looks at him, knows his expression is pathetic, a little desperate, maybe. Because then Mike sighs, and drags his hand down his face like Steve is unloading some great burden onto his judgement. “Have you thought about how, just maybe, this is a massive fucking trap? Even if you aren’t insane and—you are really seeing this, how would Eddie be alive again?”

 

When Steve doesn’t pipe up, Mike presses on. “Dustin said Eddie was so—like, so dead. Nearly in two halves dead. The Upside Down is a fucked up place, maybe it brought him back, or whatever, but—it would have to be for a reason, right? Come on, Steve. Why are you the only one seeing this shit? Something—something is trying to lure you. Maybe Vecna, maybe the Mind Flayer.”

 

Biting at his lip, Mike stuffs his hands into his pockets, unable to stand firmly in the same spot of his front lawn. “Just—come talk to everyone about it. Like we always do. I can buzz the Party, call Hopper—we can talk about it. But you can’t just go to the Upside Down like it’s a gas station, or some shit. El sealed the gates. How are you planning on getting through again?”

 

Unconsciously, Steve’s hand wraps around the handle of his bat. Mike looks at him incredulously. 

 

“You’re just gonna smash your way through? If that worked, the scientists at the lab would’ve destroyed Hawkins years ago,” Mike rolls his eyes, exasperation oozing from his every pore. “God, you’re an idiot.”

 

Sighing, Steve pushes himself onto his feet, slowly to try and save his head from the relentless spinning of the hours following tequila. “Twenty minutes, Wheeler,”

 

Mike’s hands find his hips, lines of confusion and indignance carving into his face like damaged pottery. “What?”

 

“Give me twenty minutes,” Steve says, hand firm on his bat. “Twenty minute head start. When it’s been twenty minutes—do your worst. Call Hopper, call the calvary—just give me twenty minutes.” 

 

There’s a pause in which Mike seems to think, face scrunched up like a pug, scrutinizing Steve’s every word. “Where are you even going?” 

 

“There’s three gates. That’s, like—a high probability you’ll find me quick,” Steve was never much of a maths man, but as he wheels one of the bikes leaned up against the house back over to Mike, he gets a stingy look suggesting his odds are pretty shit. 

 

Mike’s arms wrap around himself, protective, defensive. “Twenty minutes. You won’t get through the gate anyway, but—”

 

His hesitance stops Steve as he prepares to cycle away, shifting to turn back and stare expectantly for the rest of the sentence. 

 

The hardness of Mike’s expression melts away into a more blatant, heart-aching concern. “Steve—if you do get through, just… don’t. Be as stupid as you are usually, right? This is a fucking trap, and if you get in there and die immediately it’ll be really embarrassing for you,”

 

“Yeah,” Steve says, trying to keep his confusion out of his voice. 

 

He fails, clearly—Mike looks frustrated, balling his fists at his sides. “Listen, just—Dustin, right? He’s already lost Eddie. And when Max told us you thought he was alive, we all—made sure he didn’t hear that shit, cuz we thought you were just losing your goddamn mind. Drinking and hiding in your house, whatever—” Swallowing thickly, Mike drags a hand through his own hair, displacing the unruly order of his bangs. 

 

“If you die too, especially—when you haven’t been speaking to him. He’ll be destroyed. Like, totally destroyed. He’s barely even functioning right now, asshole, so if you—” Then the unimaginable happens. 

 

Mike brings his fists up to his face, and starts to cry. 

 

Steve has never seen Mike cry. Never. Not even when he was a kid, when Billy came around and frightened the shit out of them all, not even when he almost lost his mind over El having some creature in her leg at the Battle of Starcourt Mall. 

 

But here he is, sobbing in the middle of the night on his own front lawn, hiccuping and trembling in a totally uncharacteristic display of distress. 

 

Steve drops the bike, drops his bat—stumbles over it to grab Mike by the shoulders, strong-arming him into a hug. It’s awkward and uncertain, they’ve never hugged before, nor wanted to—Mike was always one of his kids, but always the furthest, the most bitter and stubborn. 

 

But it’s a hug. And eventually Mike gives in, his arms falling away from his face and sitting limp at his sides, allowing for Steve to pull him against his chest. 

 

They stay like that—Mike’s shoulders heaving and releasing in a push and pull of exhaustion and weariness. It’s only now, Steve curling his hand against the expanse of Mike’s back, trying to console whatever this is—does he think about it.

 

Even as they stand now, Mike is wearing his Hellfire Club shirt. 

 

Eddie meant a lot to Dustin, there’s no doubt about that. Steve knew it, envied it, then loved it, lost it. But he’d never considered the other boys, Lucas, Mike—even Max, who’d lived across the way from Eddie, a feature in her life whether he meant to be or not. 

 

Then there was everything else. Mike almost losing his best friend to the dangers of the Upside Down, having to be on the sidelines while his girlfriend took her mind, body and soul to the brink of destruction to save them all. It can’t be easy.

 

Steve’s eyes find the darkness of the Wheeler house, the pretty suburban picture. He thinks about Mike in that big house, his parents always there but not really. Never being able to understand him, Mike never being able to speak to them about why he’s hurting. He’s alone in that house, alone in his struggles because in the Party there’s always someone who has it worse, always someone suffering more. 

 

So Steve brings Mike into a bone-breaking hold, squeezes the air out of him and tries not to think too hard about how he understands, knowing it could spill out from his lips in a disaster of words and emotions, knowing he’d scare Mike off for good. 

 

“Don’t die,” Mike says after a sharp intake of breath, shoving Steve off of him roughly. “If you die I’ll never fucking forgive you. It’ll destroy the Party forever. Twenty fucking minutes and then I’m calling everyone.” Then he scrubs at his face with the cotton of his sleeve, breath staggered and ruined. “Twenty minutes starting now, Steve, get the fuck out of here!” 

 

Taking the bike back into his hands, Steve shoves his bat in the space under his arm, tensing his body to keep it there as he pushes off of the pavement. It takes every scrap of self-control he has to not look back, entirely too aware of the soft spot he has for those damn kids, because one glance back to Mike could make him give in altogether.

 

Steve can’t give in. He can’t listen and wait, because if he waits for the group to gather and make a plan Eddie might be dead again by the time they get there. 

 

And that’s if anyone listens to him anyway. What if they don’t? What if Steve tells them everything and nobody believes him as they haven’t been, if they think he’s completely insane, in denial or worse—some victim of Vecna; the Upside Down. 

 

They’d dismiss him. Make sure he didn’t do anything stupid. Eddie would be abandoned, left to fend for himself and die all over again. 

 

Steve can’t take that risk. So he peddles—hard enough to set a campfire up in his muscles, limbs aching and burning as he pelts it up the winding roads of Hawkins at god-knows what time. He feels the comforting lull of the alcohol he’d drank spark up and fizzle out, sweating it out from the exertion of traveling across the entire town by bike. 

 

Occasionally he has to stop, a handgun or pack of ammo toppling from his pockets leaving him to stumble off the seat and scuff his shoes on the curb trying to retrieve his lost goods. Every second of stupidity or fumbling only makes the time limit he’s bartered with Mike glaringly obvious in the back of his mind, a reminder that he needs to hurry up. 

 

Because man, if Hopper knew what he was about to do, he’d absolutely throw him in jail. Steve doesn’t have to be a genius to know that this is really, really stupid. But Nancy’s always been the one with the brains and the plans, Robin’s his smarter, better half and Eddie was the comedic relief, the realist—Steve was the guy who hits shit really hard and used himself as a meat shield to protect everyone else.

 

That didn’t require brains. So this plan, if it can be called that—is absent of any. 

 

Something that is once again really clear when Steve wheels his stolen bike into the trailer park and remembers at the very last minute that Max lives here too, even if her bedroom light is off. She’s not really slept all that well for a while, judging by the times the voice mail tells Steve her occasional, furious messages to him were recorded. 

 

One wrong move and she startles like a street cat. Screw calling the others—Max would undoubtedly find some way to take Steve down and tie him to a radiator, or something. 

 

So Steve is careful. His liquid courage has drained out of him, left with the sickly aftertaste of being sober, his only motivator fear. He creeps, slipping under the yellow police tape cordoning off Eddie’s old trailer, surprised to find the door unlocked.

 

(In hindsight, he should’ve thought about that a little more. Despite the incompetence of the police force after Hopper’s “death” nobody leaves a crime scene unlocked.)

 

The gate is above-head, pulsing, angry, red. It’s straining against whatever El had used to seal it, throbbing like a vital organ freshly cut from a human body. It’s visceral, turning Steve’s stomach as he takes his bat, trying to push himself to swing at it before he loses the will to. 

 

There’s a click by his ear. 

 

“Don’t move,” Follows a gruff, rasping voice, the cool metal of what he assumes to be the butt of a gun pressed against the back of his skull. Whoever this is clearly intends to imply they can shoot him dead, military style. 

 

Is the military still here? It’s Steve’s first thought, he’d stumbled on a leftover night watch, one of the lab goons sent to guard the gate, maybe even try and see if they can open it up again, the bastards. 

 

“Y’got five goddamn seconds t’state y’case, boy, or I’ll blow that pretty head’a yours wide open,” Is groused into his ear. When Steve hesitates, a fist takes his hair and pulls, forcing him to turn at an unnatural angle by his neck, straining his eyes to the face of his attacker. 

 

Oh, man. That makes a lot more sense. 

 

It’s Wayne Munson. 

 

He’s dressed in scruffy, worker’s denim, face marred with the sort of anger grief can only spur, scorn and scrutiny sparking the only light in his dark, familiar eyes. 

 

He’s got Eddie’s eyes, Steve notes. Deep and thoughtful, the window to the soul—in this case, Wayne’s only deferring characteristic away from this burning rage, a stark contrast to his nephew. Eddie’s eyes were a gaping hole in the part he played, the raw emotions he’d hide behind a curtain of rebellion and playful defiance swimming in the depths of their pretty browns and hazels. 

 

Steve realizes when Wayne cocks a brow that he’d been doing way too much staring and way too little talking. 

 

“You’re the Harrington kid,” Comes the accusation, eyes narrowing. “Guess I shoulda known by the hair,” Forcing a laugh out of his throat like he tends to do in most life or death situations, Steve keeps his body tense in its awkward position, nervously smiling at Eddie’s uncle. 

 

“Hi,” He musters, swallowing because there’s very much still a gun leveled at his head, and that’s the sort of head injury he won’t come back from like he had his others. 

 

Wayne doesn’t look impressed by his lack of panicked explanation, but shoves him out of his grip all the same, lowering the gun he’d aimed,  though not disarming himself. “Why’re you here, Harrington? Guessed you were one’a them kids here to try and destroy what I’ve got left of my Ed, but them folk told me you were one of the lot down there,” 

 

Down there, meaning the Upside Down.

 

They must have told him—even if it was the bare minimum of need-to-know. The government can explain away a portal growing in the ceiling of his home, but when his nephew died in the world that opening leads to—that’s harder to brush off. 

 

Steve had assumed they’d moved him someplace else, someplace nicer to try and make the bitter pill of loss easier to swallow. One look at Wayne, now they face each other, and Steve reasons that they had—Wayne grips something in his other hand, a bundle of clothing, a shirt maybe. 

 

Probably Eddie’s. He feels a little sick, a lot awful, he’d disturbed Wayne’s grief, though neither of them should be here the man had far more right to be. 

 

“I, uh. I left something,” Steve says, mouth dry. 

 

Wayne’s eyebrows raise again. “In my trailer?”

 

“No,” He looks up without really thinking, staring at the growth on the ceiling. 

 

If Wayne’s eyebrows went any higher, they’d slip off of his head entirely. “You… left somethin’ in there? Special ‘nuff to drag your sorry self back?”

 

Teeth finding his lip, Steve gnaws, anxious. “Yeah,”

 

The gun is pointed back in his direction. “Get the fuck outta here. Either y’still lyin’ to me or y’just plain fuckin’ stupid. Y’wanna go back there, boy? After what it did to my Ed?” It’s a blatant accusation, a token of offense taken, the nose of the gun shaking in Wayne’s trembling hands. 

 

“I know your father, boy .” He uses the word with venom, authority; a reminder that Steve is young and dumb. “He’s a cruel man, a slimy rich mother fucker . Thought he’d raise ya to be just like ‘im, turns out he’s raised ya to be a goddamn mother fucking idiot ,” 

 

One fist gathering the front of Steve’s shirt, Wayne pushes him up against the inner wall of the trailer, pressing the gun up to the curve where his chin meets his jaw.

 

It’s painfully reminiscent of Eddie with the broken bottle against his neck, expression raw with fear and actions riddled with a wild desperation. 

 

Their mannerisms are mirrored, Wayne’s older, slower, but still the root in which Eddie’s grew. The way their brows crease in the wrath of fear, the lopsided downturn of their mouths. The way they hold their shoulders, the way their arms tremble, saving the force for the fists. 

 

This is the man who raised him, nurtured him, loved him. Who built him up to be witty and fond and proud, bright and brave until the end. If anyone deserves to know, to believe, it’s him. 

 

“He’s alive,” Steve says firmly, and wholeheartedly knows it to be true. 

 

Wayne’s face creases with a pained fury, a desperate sadness pooling through his eyes. “Y’gotta be cruel to play games like this with an old man, boy,” There’s nothing to punctuate the end of the sentence, it’s left open—capable to suggestion, continuation. It’s an invitation for Steve to continue, to persuade, comfort. 

 

“I’m not,” Steve whispers, biting back the need to cry. “He spoke to me—through the lights. He, the… morse code, he did the S.O.S. signal, he needs me. He—He’s who I have to go back for. I left him,”

 

“He was dead when y’left him,” Wayne says, tears gathering at the corners of his eyes, frustration coating his grief in a thick varnish. 

 

Steve curves his hand to grip the wrist that keeps the gun steady against his chin, squeezing lightly. “I know he’s not dead anymore. I feel it,” It’s a weak argument, but Wayne’s grip seems to falter. “If I’m wrong, you can shoot me when I get back.”

 

Wayne pushes himself off of Steve in a rough, harsh motion, turning on his heel and stuffing the gun into his pants. “Shut up, boy. If ya lyin’ to me I’ll bury ya where my boy should be lyin’. But you ain’t, and I know you ain’t, so if ya wrong when we get back I won’t do shit to you,” He looks back, pulling a heavy coat over his work clothes. 

 

“From the looks of it you’ve been sufferin’ hell’of a’nuff over my Ed. If ya wrong, I know ya can punish y’self far better than I could,” And he reads him, sifts through him like a hardback copy of a novel, drags the pads of his fingers along the pages of Steve and closes him sharply, leaving him to feel exposed, confused. 

 

(Eddie could do that too, Steve thinks to himself. Read him and leave him open, ready for the insult or mockery that should come with such a thing, yet never finding it.) 

 

Then Steve falters. “Wait—when we get back? Mr Munson, uh, no?”

 

“Call me Wayne,” He says, before jostling Steve around and plucking the shotgun off of his back. “Jesus, boy. Y’know this here’s a felony? Sawing off shotguns like this? S’good idea, though,” Wayne hums appreciatively, taking the handle of the Makarov and stealing that, too. 

 

“Hey— hey, what? Uh, Wayne, sir, this is not happening,” Steve tosses his hair out of his face, making an X motion with his arms. “You can’t—come with me, it’s insane down there and you’ve never… seen what’s down there before. No way,”

 

Wayne fiddles with the severed barrel of the shotgun, sliding the Makarov into his belt before fixing Steve a bemused look. “I said call me Wayne, not sir, boy. I’m not your goddamn army officer,” Then he cocks the shotgun, squinting into it. “I did serve in Korea, though,” And then he snaps it back shut, slipping it under his arm. 

 

“Uh—Wayne,” It feels wrong on Steve’s tongue, almost disrespectful. “It’s… it’s bad down there.”

 

“And my boy’s down there, so ya sayin’, Harrington. My boy’s down there and if y’gonna go get him, like hell is it gonna be without me.” Wayne claps Steve on the shoulder, almost in an act of camaraderie, and moves them both to stand under the gate. One finger pointing up, Wayne gives a firm nod. “Y’gonna pop that thing open. And we’re gonna fight our way through whatever the shit is in our way to gettin’ my boy home.”

 

Steve tries to protest, but the stern look on Wayne’s face is so painfully Eddie, it’s difficult to muster the courage to do so. The man seems to sense this, and gives him a squeeze for the trouble. “This is my home, Harrington. I know ya pops wanted us trailer trash gone and in another town, but he ain’t succeeded yet.” Guilt drips off of him in gentle droves, but Wayne doesn’t say it maliciously, just matter-of-factly. 

 

“This is my home, Harrington. Y’ain’t gonna tell a man what he can and can’t do in his own home, are ya, Steven?” Wayne smacks a hand into the dead-center of his back, encouraging, gruff. 

 

“Steve,” He corrects, still a little wide-eyed, a deer on ice. Unsteady and unprepared. Wayne’s face breaks into a brusque smile, rippling crotchety wrinkles up his rough skin. 

 

“Steve,” Wayne echoes. “This is my home. Eddie’s my boy.” And then he ruffles his hair with one large hand, coarse from years of working with them, in an action that reminds Steve of Hopper. The instinct to father; seek that kind of passing paternal affection. It makes his chest ache, a cavern of something missing, makes him want to flee the same way he does whenever Hopper wrangles an arm around his shoulder and calls him kid. 

 

“I’m gonna go down there and get my boy back. You’re gonna be my tour guide.” He holds his hand out for the final gun Steve has stashed, which he gives over reluctantly. He finds Wayne remarkably difficult to argue with—wonders if Eddie found the same. “Tour guides don’t need guns. You point at somethin’, I shoot it. Got it, Steve?”

 

Steve knows his face must be the most amusing picture of shock, because Wayne just cracks open another grin and angles his head back up to the gate. “You gonna get that baby open or what, boy?”

 

Dragging a hand down the damp skin of his face, Steve sighs with every inch of exhaustion he’s collected on his journey to get here, limply shaking his head. Scouring the floor of the trailer, he sweeps a wonky chair from the kitchen, placing it just underneath the pulsating growth on the ceiling. 

 

“Can you, uh, pass me the shotgun, sir?” Steve says sheepishly, balanced haphazardly on the seat. Wayne looks unimpressed, maybe by Steve’s refusal to use his name or the demand for his very illegal shotgun—but either way, offers it up to him. 

 

Angling the butt of it against the scarlet, muscle-like wall, Steve closes one eye and squints, giving it a firm prod. When it doesn’t so much as shift or complain, he sighs, splaying his hand out against the flesh of the gate. 

 

Distant, he hears Wayne complain about his obvious lack of planning, sees him shuffle around the trailer, packing up supplies, and tinned food. His grumbles fall on deaf ears, fed to Steve through a small funnel of noise, his brain entirely consumed by a ferocious buzzing. A swarm, a polyphony of damp, cool organs and agencies speaking to him, welcoming him. 

 

Steve is a key to a lock Eleven forged through blood, sweat and tears. 

 

Faintly, Mike’s insistence that this sounded like a trap begins to ring true. 

 

But when the flesh begins to part, curling in on itself to open the partition to the hellscape above or beneath them, Steve abandons all sense. Any scrap of logical thinking he was still capable of is dead and buried, because the gate just opened for him. 

 

For him. 

 

It’s not right—it’s grotesque, a visceral sensation in his gut as the Upside Down whispers to him in greeting, a mangled reunion. The gate should not open, not like this, not so easily. The bite wounds climbing his side like ivy on cobblestone ripple, chirping in some malformed communication. Flesh to flesh. 

 

“Wayne,” Steve coughs out, trying to draw his focus away from the intoxicating lull of the gate, the gradually exposed dimension unraveling before them. “It’s—not meant to do that,”

 

The man shifts closer to him, brow furrowed in one deep, jagged line across his forehead. “Ain’t nothin’ right about that goddamn thing, Steve, boy.” It looks like he might even ask him to get down off the chair, one hand reaching to jostle the sleeve of Steve’s thick army jacket, but quickly that becomes futile. 

 

Just like the sudden peril that was Lover’s Lake, Steve’s only warning of danger was Wayne’s loose grasp turning into a deadlock grip around his one wrist, the other pulsing as the flesh of a vine coiled around the bone of the other. 

 

The pound of writhing flesh pulls taut, and heaves, finding no struggle in taking the combined weight of Steve and Wayne up and through the gate, no mattress on the other side to save them from the impact on the other side. Steve hears Wayne groan, a flash of hot guilt curling in his gut—but he hadn’t the time to dwell, because the vine doesn’t stop now they’re stuck on the other side. 

 

No, it only grows more wild, drawing a sharp yell of surprise out of Steve when it blasts through the plaster of the Upside Down’s equivalent to the Munson trailer, determined to drag him with it. 

 

Wayne’s grip on him falters, the flesh snatching Steve from his grip in an action all too reminiscent of the time before, sprawled out on his back as the malformed version of the trailer park travels by him in a swift, snakelike whip of predatory retrieval. 

 

Managing to snag his hand on the oxidized metal of the gates to the park, Steve bites back the cry he desperately wants to heave out, the wiring cutting into the flesh of his fingers as he fights the strength of the vine for just a second longer. 

 

This moment—the jagged second in which he halts the relentless drag of the vine—is when Steve is taught a valuable lesson. Do not underestimate Wayne Munson.

 

Because with an iron grip of determination forged into his expression, Wayne pounds across the trailer park grounds, body sharp and limber. He moves with practice; honed and trained, even if the tolls of time have roughened the edges of a careful runner’s stance, dulled the end of the dexterous posture he travels with. 

 

He’s on the vine in a handful of crucial seconds, tossing his body to the decrepit floors of the Upside Down, rolling once and skidding to a stop. One hand drawing a blade from his combat boot, Wayne uses the other to gather the flesh of the vine in his fist, sinking his nails into the viscera and using his newfound leverage to stab down, through and out. 

 

Wayne severs the tail of the vine that’s coiled its way around Steve’s appendages, sending it squealing and wailing in a hasty retreat back to whatever creature it adheres to. 

 

Steve lays flat on his back, shock trickling through to his major extremities as he attempts to let that entire sequence settle in. 

 

Wayne is staring at his hand with a vague interest and blatant disgust, huffing before wiping it on his pant leg. “Well ain’t this place just the picture of fucked up?” 

 

Remembering that in times where someone has just saved your life that it’s generally good manners to thank the man responsible, Steve splutters, brain not reaching his tongue. Several different phrases flicker through his thoughts, most of them groveling or ass-kissing, not suitable for a man so gruff, so totally, surprisingly yet undeniably badass. 

 

Pondering once again over Wayne being Eddie’s uncle, Steve comes to a decision—what would Eddie say?

 

“That was so—so fucking metal, sir,” It comes out wrong, definitely poser-ish, and the sir at the end just has Steve cringing, but Wayne turns and chuckles, offering a fond, brusque smile all the same. A hand is offered to him in an effort to get him off the ground. 

 

“You’ve been spendin’ too much time with my boy, I can goddamn tell. Up we get now, son,” Tugging him upright, Wayne steadies him with a hand on his shoulder, checks him over quickly. He seems relatively content with Steve’s lack of obvious injury, clapping him on the back and encouraging him to walk. “Lead the way, kid, we’ve got ground to cover,”

 

Several things stick out to Steve in what Wayne had just said, multiple worth mentioning, contending, dwelling upon. But in times like this Steve becomes blatantly aware of just how shit he is at talking to adults— older adults, he corrects, because technically Steve is, legally, an adult. 

 

Trailing after men like Wayne Munson or Chief Hopper, he really doesn’t feel like it. 

 

All the same, Steve swallows, stumbles over himself and does his best to pretend he knows the way to his own house. 

 

“I, uh. I didn’t get to spend a lot of time with him,” Steve admits, glancing back at Wayne, who’s adjusting the rucksack of supplies he’d had the intelligence to bring. He doesn’t have time to dwell on the fact that he hadn’t thought that far—Wayne is staring at him expectantly. 

 

“We… hung with different crowds. At school,” Steve adds, shifting Wayne’s facial expression from bemused to straight up incredulous. 

 

He spins Nancy’s handgun on one hand. “You don’t say, Harrington,” Wayne says his surname like that says enough, gaze pointed. “I think I woulda known if you were hangin’ round my boy. Y’father woulda taped an eviction notice to his head and sent ‘im back to me.” A scoff. “Ain’t no way his Harrington boy would be hangin’ with trailer trash,”

 

Mouth dry, Steve steps over a shifting vine in the dirt, Wayne mirroring his caution without a word. “I would’ve. Definitely, if… I’d known him the way I do now.”

 

“I don’t think so,” Wayne says, though not maliciously. “Your varsity pals woulda made quick work of him, no doubt. Boys like that cockroach, that Jason Carver lad.”

 

Steve swings his bat lightly and idly in one hand, the urge to keep them occupied when uncomfortable conversations like this come to fruition unbearable to resist. “Maybe in junior year, yeah. But, uh, after… after I fought a creature from here for the first time?” He gestures to the sky with his nail-stricken weapon, chuckling dryly. “Eddie would’ve been right up my alley. I’m actually kinda jealous of him, to be honest,”

 

Though Wayne continues to have one eyebrow raised, his expression is softer, stance less tense when angled towards him. “You, a Harrington, in that nice, big house? Jealous of my boy?”

 

“Yeah,” Steve says, gently kicking a piece of rubble from his path as they edge into the beginnings of the forest. “I know it’s stupid, I know… I’ve got way more shit than people could dream of. But Eddie, you know, he was just… is just, like, him. Crazy and loud and a total freak, and it’s… really fucking awesome.”

 

Wayne nods at that, no harsh quip to cut through Steve’s fumbling honesty. “Ed’s a lotta things, but he’s almost always ‘imself, and he ain’t got that from me. I was always a little worried, y’know?” He knocks his shoulder against Steve’s as they make their own path around the Upside Down debris. “Your types always gave him trouble. Sayin’ all sorts, I’m sure you can guess. I always said shit like… maybe just tone it down, Eds, give it up a little.”

 

There’s a grief to that, a bitter regret. 

 

“I’m glad he ain’t listen to me all that much. If he is, y’know… if he’s dead, my boy, he died true to ‘imself. And I know he’d like that a…” Wayne looks Steve up and down. “Preppy guy such as y’self was lookin’ to stray from his image a little.” 

 

A shriek cuts through the thick, humid blanket of their whispering, stopping both Wayne and Steve short. They’re stock-still, standing, listening—Steve instinctively holding up one hand in front of Wayne. 

 

The older man slaps it away with a grimace. 

 

“I don’t think it knows where we are,” Steve hisses, continuing his stride, though slower, footfalls lighter. 

 

Wayne chuckles wryly, shaking his head. “Dunno if I should be grateful that I don’t know what an it is in this shit’ole,”

 

Casting a pained look back to him over his shoulder, Steve gnaws at his lip. “Demogorgon. Like, seven, eight feet tall… no face. Lots of teeth,”

 

“It got no face but it got teeth?” Wayne echoes, face the picture of horrified fascination. 

 

Shuddering, Steve resists the urge to gag. “Yeah, dude—sir. Wayne .” He gets there in the end. “Shit, like… it’s almost like a flower? Opens up and man, you don’t wanna be there when it closes. Pop you like a grape,”

 

“Just how long’ve you kids been fighting these mother fucking things?” If Wayne’s hand tightens a little on the butt of the shotgun, Steve can’t say he blames him. 

 

Squinting up at the sky, Steve tries to do the math, and gives it up quicker than he should’ve. “Y’know when Will Byers went missing?”

 

“Yeah, I know lil’ Will Byers. Buncha guys from the plant checked round the ground just ‘case he’d fallen or somethin’.” Wayne recollects, eyes flicking from Steve to the red daggers of lightning in the Upside Down’s sky. 

 

“Demogorgon took him, broke through a gate like the one in your trailer. I had no idea what was even, like… happening, it was just,” Steve shrugs, glancing back down to the bat in his hands. “Right place, wrong time, or… wrong place, wrong time? I don’t know,” The phrasing is lost, so he abandons it. “I came around to apologize to his older brother, Jonathan,”

 

“Yeah, I remember my Ed talkin’ bout the scrap between you two,” Wayne offers. 

 

Steve nods. “Went to apologize, and a creature climbed out of his ceiling and we fought it together. With Nancy, too. And it fucked me up good.” Casting another gaze to the ruined environment of the Upside Down, Steve chuckles. “Hard to care about being prom king or basketball when you’ve nearly died because of some monster from… another world. Everyone thought I’d gone insane,”

 

There’s another indescribable expression carved into Wayne’s face, one hand curling around the handle of the shotgun methodically. Almost self-soothing. “I think some of the guys at work were sayin’ they had boys at the school talkin’ bout some King Steve Harrington losing the plot. Can't say I… blame you,” 

 

Wayne pointedly takes a step over another thick vine sprawled out on the ground. 

 

“Yeah,” Steve mumbles, struggling to look back at the older man. “Then shit just kept happening. I ended up babysitting a bunch of kids, then… those kids went to high school and became Eddie’s kids. And I was jealous of him, and shit, ’til I realized they need us both. All the help they can get,” 

 

Clapping a hand over his shoulder, Wayne gives Steve a heavy squeeze, releasing him with a bit too much vigor, though well-meaning. “That Henderson boy.” 

 

“Dustin, yeah, man… he’s like my brother. I always wanted one and shit, he’s annoying, but. That’s what it’s like with a brother,” There’s a strange tension to Wayne after Steve declares that, a part of him wondering if he was Eddie’s uncle through his father. If that was the reason Eddie lived with him. 

 

If this went the way Steve wanted it to, he’d ask Eddie himself. 

 

“Since Eddie, though, it’s… not been right,” He admits, trying to shift the conversation away from what he doesn’t know about Wayne. The look on his face says that so? And Steve nods. “I don’t think Dustin’s gonna forgive me for… leaving him. So I gotta bring him back,”

 

Wayne frowns, shooting Steve a look riddled with disapproval. “Now I’m sure that ain’t the case. It won’t be for my Ed, I’ll tell ya that. He hears you sayin’ that kinda shit and he’ll smack the back of y’head so hard you’ll see stars, son,” 

 

There’s an argument on the tip of Steve’s tongue, the constant threat of tears itching in the corners of his eyes. As he goes to try and explain to Eddie’s only relative who cares for him just how Steve left him for dead, Wayne’s arm suddenly snaps out, grabbing him by the scruff of his jacket. 

 

Confusion swimming in his expression, Steve turns to question Wayne, only to find a hand pressed over his mouth. 

 

There’s a rustle. It’s quiet, but there’s a disruption in the rotting leaves just a few feet to their left. 

 

Steve feels his blood run cold. 

 

“We’re going to run,” Wayne says, still, under his breath. Steve can’t tell him that it’s fucking impossible to outrun a Demogorgon, not with his hand pressed over his mouth, and a part of him thinks maybe that’s why he’s put it there. “ Now,”

 

They break apart, sprinting in the same direction but not side by side, zigzagging and snaking over foliage and the rotting corpses of trees, Steve thankful for his only additional weight the light wood of his bat in-hand. 

 

Despite bearing the weight of the artillery and their supplies, Wayne is a few meters ahead of him, weaving and ducking his way through the Upside Down’s deformed woods, looking back only to check that Steve was with him. 

 

If he couldn’t hear the frustrated screeches of the Demogorgon practically licking at his heels, Steve would’ve been touched at the sentiment. 

 

It can’t go on like this—last time they’d been on home turf, the Byers’ house theirs to manipulate. This was the Demogorgon’s home, with every sodden footfall on the rotten earth they step closer to a trap they can’t know about, a new monster lurking in the mutilated shadows of the Upside Down. 

 

Some twisted fate hears Steve’s prayers, because Wayne suddenly vanishes from his view, leaving no time to fret as they both take an unavoidable plunge headfirst down a steep hill, stumbling and then rolling in the rot. 

 

Flares of pain jab and scald his body, debris and decay blemishing and soiling his clothes, skin, hair. He feels it seep into his flesh as he tumbles, the earth so putrefied that it bleeds into him, soaking every inch of his being until he finds himself gagging, unable to do more in the flailing panic of his plummet. 

 

His body comes to a stop after colliding with the hollow trunk of a tree, the sap bitter where it should be sweet. 

 

A quiet groan nearby offers Steve a minor comfort. Eddie’s uncle survived whatever strategy the two of them had just mutually employed—so he rolls onto his stomach, commando crawling over to where Wayne lies, splayed out on his back. 

 

There’s a calling trill at the top of the clearing, the Demogorgon shrieking and vocalizing clear dismay over losing lunch and dinner in one fail swoop. The way it calls almost sounds as if it wants the two of them to reply, something that could earn a laugh from Steve if he weren’t almost entirely convinced the monster would hear and make sure they didn’t get lucky again. 

 

Though as he wipes the ineffable muck off of his brow, Steve can’t say he feels so lucky. 

 

“It can’t see,” He recalls, speaking only after ten minutes of lying in the grime with Wayne by his side. “It—smells and hears. This…” Steve flicks his wrist, slick rot from the decaying earth dripping from his fingertips. “Probably just makes us smell of… y’know,”

 

“Shit?” Wayne offers, clutching his side. 

 

Steve shrugs. “I was gonna say everything else, but… yeah, that, too. God, there’s nothing like an Upside Down shower, man,”

 

There’s a pause in which Wayne’s face just scrunches up, and Steve realizes he sounds just a little stretch past insane, one foot in total maniac. 

 

“It’s like—I haven’t been to the coast in ages, but when you come back from the beach all sandy and shit and you get to shower it off. Like… a beach shower, but for the Upside Down. Showering that shit off almost makes up for it being all over you in the first place,” Steve explains, though the incredulity on Wayne’s face only grows, wrinkling across his skin in distaste. 

 

“You’re a weird one, son,” Wayne grumbles, dragging a hand down his face, trying to rid himself of some of the rot, though only really succeeding in smearing it further. “I can see why my Ed and y’self are… all buddy buddy,” 

 

There’s a pause, and then something warm blooms in Steve’s chest. “Really?”

 

“Goddamn, looking at me like a puppy dog,” Wayne grouses, shaking his head in disdain. “Ain’t seen nobody so happy to be called weird.”

 

Bashful, Steve sits up against the decaying tree that had stopped his fall, bringing his knees up to sit criss-crossed. “I dunno. It kinda felt like a compliment coming from Eddie, so… coming from you,”

 

“It weren’t a compliment, don’t letcha ego blow y’self up,” Wayne snipes, before a snarky grin blossoms over his face, stabbing cool relief into Steve’s gut. “Ya definitely a bit goddamn freaky. But my Ed digs that, and… here y’are. In the fuckin’ gates’a hell just to rescue ‘im.”

 

“If I didn’t know any better, Steve, I’d say you ‘n my Ed were already pals. Ain’t ever heard of acquaintances riskin’ they goddamn lives in another dimension for one another,” There’s an implication, there. Steve can feel it, woven into the careful tone Wayne uses to navigate his sentences, shifting his tired body to sit beside him. The rotting tree acts as their buffer, a shield against whatever Wayne seems to offer him, cautious. 

 

Steve thinks about Eddie wearing his jacket, HARRINGTON splayed between his shoulder blades. 

 

“Yeah, well, he said I was metal and… something about an Ozzy guy, so I think we’re best friends, actually,” He’s joking, trying to ease the tension around whatever conversation Wayne is trying to brace him for—but all he succeeds in doing is colouring a new kind of shock into the older man’s face. 

 

Wayne blinks. Looking a little stunned. “Ozzy? Ozzy Osbourne? The—Black Sabbath guy?” 

 

Steve shrugs, a bit listless. “Uh, yeah. The guy who bit the bat?”

 

“My— my nephew… compared ya to Ozzy Osbourne? Truthfully ‘n honestly?” 

 

Swallowing, Steve nods, the tiniest prickle of fear in his gut gnawing at him that maybe it was some kind of veiled insult after all. “I mean, yeah, I—don’t really know what he meant by it, but… yeah,”

 

“Jesus,” Wayne mutters, pinching his brow. “It means my nephew likes ya a helluva lot more than he’s been letting ya think, son.” He fiddles with a flask of water freshly plucked from his bag, offering it to Steve, who accepts it readily. “My boy, he… I mean, he’s practically in love with the guy,”

 

He’s testing the waters. Steve knows he is; can feel Wayne swimming for a response, side eye burning into his peripheral vision. 

 

“Oh yeah?” Steve smiles, despite the nerves, and wipes his mouth with the back of his hand. “He cute?” 

 

Any remaining stiffness between strangers melts away as Wayne muffles his laugh with the sleeve of his jacket, his other hand reaching to aggressively ruffle Steve’s hair, much to his amused dismay. “God, I can see the two of ya givin’ me one damn headache when this shit is said and done.”

 

“I’ll make sure of it,” Steve says with his parent-winning smile, batting his eyelashes. 

 

“You’re a little shit, is what y’are,” Wayne stands, knocking back another gulp of water and stuffing it back into the rucksack, sticking a firm hand out for Steve to take. “Let’s go get my boy. He can tell ya how goddamn cute y’are or y’aren’t when we got all three pairs of our fuckin’ feet back on our turf.”

 

Chuckling, Steve takes it, stumbling forwards as they set off down the steep hill on foot, a lopsided smile tilted Wayne’s way. “What? You don’t think I’m cute?” He frowns, trying to look as affronted as possible. 

 

Wayne smacks him up the back of his head, shoving him forwards. “Shut ya damn mouth, kid, or I’ll find another cliff to roll ya off of,” 






 




As they turn another corner of the decrepit, malnourished version of Hawkins’ endless suburban maze, Steve takes a second to catch his breath, bubbling pain rippling up his torso in the scarred flesh of his bat bites.

 

There’s something wrong with them—it’s almost as if they’re trying to communicate with the fucked up life here; remind Steve what could happen should he slip up for even a moment. 

 

Hands holding his knees as he bends for just a second of aching reprieve, Steve glances up to find Wayne staring at him, one eyebrow raised. 

 

“You’re really…” Steve clutches his side. “Fast. Like, you’ve got… serious form? Did you play sports in highschool or something?”

 

There’s a reluctance to Wayne’s stance, like he’s not entirely sure that’s a rabbit hole he wants Steve to chase him down, but eventually he slows to a stop, letting him take a moment to recover. “Are you injured, boy?”

 

Damn, that wasn’t the conversation Steve wanted to have, especially not considering just what injured him. (And just what killed Eddie.) “No, nah. It’s just left over from last time I was here. It’s all scarred over and stuff, ugly as shit but probably just, like… a ghostly pain.” 

 

“Phantom pain?” Wayne echoes, one hand settling on his hip. The other points poignantly at Steve’s side, where, unbeknownst to him, a large wet bloodstain has begun to climb up the fabric stuck there. 

 

“ Shit. Goddamn it, fuck,” Hands trembling around the area of pain as opposed to really knowing what he’s meant to do with it, Steve flails, phantom pain becoming very real pain. But the problem came when he considered he really wasn’t lying—those wounds had been scarred over in ugly, discolored lumps and patches of skin. Mottled over his ribs, undeniably horrific to look at.

 

(And Steve didn’t look at them. He wore a shirt in the bath, and closed his eyes in the shower. He didn’t want to see them and be reminded that maybe it should’ve been him, could’ve been him that went the way Eddie did.) 

 

Then once again Wayne Munson proves to be far, far more prepared for this than Steve ever was, despite this being the first time he’s stepped foot in the Upside Down at all. Clicking his tongue, the man unravels a thick roll of bandage from his rucksack, stalking over to Steve with purpose. “Roll your shit up, son,”

 

“It’s fine,” Steve begins, but the sharp look he gets from Wayne in return is definitely convincing enough to have his fingers curl around the hem of his blood-soaked shirt and tug it up just enough to reveal the worst of the damage. The material gradually peeling off of the newly-opened wounds is enough to have him gagging with pain, Wayne’s face contorted with a gruff concern. 

 

“Ain’t look fine,” And Steve won’t look, but he can feel, feel the flesh parting and pulsing in ways that newly scarred fresh shouldn’t. It’s wet and shifting, bubbling with viscera and mutilation. “What the goddamn hell’ve ya done?” 

 

And that’s the question Steve doesn’t want to answer, because how can he even begin to explain that his injuries were the lesser versions of the ones that killed Wayne’s nephew; killed Eddie. How can he explain that these injuries were what drew his nephew into his deathbed in the first place, Steve’s failure dragging Robin, Nancy and Eddie headfirst after him. 

 

Eddie dived into danger to save Steve, and died in his place that same day. 

 

It should’ve been him—the same mantra that’s carried Steve to where he stands now, groaning softly as Wayne tries to get a better look at the mutilation of his torso, the wet wound blossoming from dry scarring. It’s unnatural, and thus comes with a malformed sort of pain, throbbing and indecent. 

 

It should’ve been him. He should’ve stayed with Dustin, stayed with Eddie. Steve knew the bats were dangerous, shouldn’t have just expected Eddie to do exactly what he said because who would? Why would anyone blindly listen to Steve, Steve with his big mouth and stupid way of making everyone want to do the opposite of what he asks. 

 

By telling Eddie not to be a hero, he must’ve made him feel inadequate. Must’ve pushed him to try and be a hero. 

 

Steve pushed Eddie, and then he died. And now Steve has to save him, because if he’s too late then this was all for nothing. He’s ripped the bandaid of grief off of Wayne, the kids, everyone—taken that from them and if he can’t get Eddie back, the damage he’s done will be irreparable. 

 

Which is why the bitter guile of self-hatred flows thick and fast through his body when he comes to notice he can’t breathe without difficulty, when his chest is tight and he can’t move. 

 

He realizes that he’s on the floor, Wayne having lowered him to the ground against a home rotting in the mildew of the Upside Down, trying to shelter them both. Steve feels hands on his shoulders, hears a steady thrum of a voice attempting to speak to him with little success.

 

“Harrington. Steve—kid, hey ?” Wayne gently taps Steve’s face with the back of his hand, stirring some focus in the milky distance in his eyes. “There y’are. Y’ok, kid, it’s—fine,”

 

There’s an awkwardness to his attempts to comfort, though it still seems practiced, learnt. No man can raise a teenager well without knowing how to do so, Steve supposes, and Eddie has undoubtedly been raised well. 

 

“Sorry,” Steve chokes out, voice thick with panic. 

 

“It’s okay,” Wayne repeats, patting the top of his head. They stay like that for another few moments, balled up against the side of the house, hidden from any creatures that may spot them from the sky. 

 

“No, I’m sorry. It’s my—it’s my fault,” Comes the pant Steve musters, words slurred together a little pathetically. Shame brings heat to his face. “I should’ve—been with him. With Eddie. He died because of me, and I’m—I’m so goddamn scared he won’t be alive by the time we find him here. If I’m too slow, or too stupid and I’ve—I’ve held you back,”

 

Anger floods Wayne’s face, spiralling crotchety wrinkles and lines of frustration up the planes of skin there, deep and sharp. “Now you shut your goddamn mouth, boy, and you listen to me,” Jabbing one firm finger into Steve’s chest, the man uses his other hand to grapple his shoulder, holding him firm. “You stop this bullshit right goddamn now, I ain’t listenin’ to ya talk y’self into this mess. Y’are a mess, kid, and my Ed would be walkin’ in goddamn circles of frustration if he heard this shit ya talkin’,”

 

Any further attempts for Steve to pipe up in disagreement are silenced when Wayne holds his shoulder and jostles him quiet. “You were there, son. My boy was havin’ the worst week of his goddamn life, chased by the pitchforks of this town and you were there. You coulda left ‘im to be alone, turned him to the cops and you ain’t do that, you stuck by him, you fed him, picked him up and you fought by him even when they was sayin’ he was a murderer. You lot you went and you found him and you made sure he knew that you knew he weren’t no killer,”

 

Wayne stops his brusque rant only to furiously scrub his sleeve over his face, displacing the tears that had gathered there. “Before you came to me, boy, I was grateful. Grateful that even if he was dead he died alongside people who believed in him, built him up and cared for him, people who grieved him. People whose lives he touched and saved,” Taking a staggered breath, the man shuts his eyes for just a moment, heaving under the raw emotion of the conversation. “And now ya tellin’ me that not only is my boy alive, but that you were gonna come down to this goddamn hell place on your own with no goddamn plan and nothing but a coupla guns y’ain’t know how to use and a fuckin’ death wish just to save him.”

 

“It ain’t your fault that he died. But it’s gonna be your fault that he lives, lives a long good mother fuckin’ life with people like you who care about him. And I know you ain’t know how special that is to me, to him, but it is. It’s just been us, son, for god knows how long,” Wayne’s hand curves around the base of Steve’s neck, thumb rubbing circles there, anxious over the sheer spill of emotions between them. “And now he’s got that Henderson kid, ‘n all his merry men in that club. He’s got that terrifyin’ gun-wieldin’ Wheeler girl, that odd little Buckley, and he got you.”

 

Pulling the roll of bandage tight around Steve’s core, Wayne’s frown deepens with concentration as he pins it quickly. Then he stands, and once again, offers his hand down for Steve to take. “Up y’get. We’re gonna find our boy, and we’re gonna get you a goddamn doctor, cuz that shit ain’t nothin’ but gnarly, kid,” He grins, fatherly and fond, when Steve can do nothing but quietly smile and take it, pulling him up with one heaving breath. 

 

They walk, side by side, shoulders occasionally brushing—a grounding tactic, a reminder that even if they’re in some hellscape, they’ve got company. Despite his guilt, Steve finds himself grateful for Wayne’s presence at his aid, strong and understanding and far, far too kind. 

 

They’re on the final stretch of street before Steve’s house when Wayne sighs, and begrudgingly admits after a long stretch of consideration, “Track,”

 

“Huh?” Steve says, lifting his head from their comfortable silence.

 

“At school. You asked if I did any sports, boy. Cap’n of the track team. I coulda run laps around any of the boys back in the day,” Wayne shakes his head in reminiscence, one hand stuffed in his pocket. 

 

Steve scoffs. “ Track? That’s a shit choice. You just run around in circles all day,”

 

“I ain’t takin’ no judgements from a meathead basketball player now am I?” Wayne gives Steve a light shove, who stumbles with a dry chuckle. 

 

“I’m just saying, out of all the more exciting options you decided running up and down was the one for you.” There’s a glint of mischief on Steve’s face, the banter between him and Wayne striking a new sense of motivation in him; an energy to utilize through the corruption suffocating the air around them. 

 

Wayne rolls his eyes, folding his arms across his chest. “I did swimmin’ too, y’goddamn shithead.”

 

“Oh, yeah?” Steve perks up, jogging a few steps ahead of Wayne so he can walk backwards, facing him with a grin. “I was the swim team captain. Maybe if I’d been born like, fifty years ago we could’ve been rivals,”

 

Coming to an abrupt stop, Wayne gawks at him, disbelief sharp in his pointed features, raw and laugh-worthy. “ Fifty years? Just how goddamn old d’ya think I am, ya little weasel? I’ll show ya fifty years—”

 

Raising his hands in mock-surrender, Steve relents, nearly tripping over the curb up to his house as he chuckles away, face scrunching. “I’m kidding. Forty years,” 

 

“Try ten,” Wayne grumbles, following him up onto the pavement. 

 

“Ten what? Decades?” And Steve earns himself a swift cuff to the back of his head, Wayne dragging him back to mess up his hair even further. 

 

Coming to a slightly stilted silence at the front door of the Harrington house, the two men let their banter fall quiet, laughs stifled to a stop in the face of the writhing vines that weave their way across the painted wood. 

 

Steve takes a breath, rolling his shoulders. One hand comes up to play with his hair a little, trying to fix it even minutely from the definite disaster it’s become—earning a wry laugh from Wayne. “Okay, Harrington, my nephew’s still gonna think ya pretty, hair messy or otherwise. Bust that shit open,”

 

Face hot, Steve bites his lip, taking the handle of his door and opening it—finding no lock to stop him. It’s bent a little out of place, he realizes, assuming it to be the handiwork of Eddie. 

 

(Briefly, he catches himself thinking about how of all the places Eddie could’ve gone, he searched the streets until he found Steve’s house. Maybe he’d been there before, dealing at one of his stupid parties. But out of everywhere in Hawkins, Eddie chose to hide at Steve’s, finding some comfort there, arms in the sleeves of Steve’s varsity jacket.)

 

Tossing his head back to dispel the hair from his eyes and thoughts of HARRINGTON spread between Eddie’s shoulder blades, Steve steps inside the distorted version of his house, the mirrored halls and walls glaring back at him. 

 

“I’d say nice place y’got, son, but…” Wayne looks to the vines slithering across the mouldy floorboards. “Y’cleaner’s been slackin’ a bit.”

 

Steve offers a wry smile in return for that comment, nerves pulling something in his heart too tight to find a better response. He climbs the stairs two at a time, yet slowly, the route to his room all too familiar. 

 

There are small differences, strange ones. The year the Upside Down stays stuck in offers a time where Steve’s parents at least held the slightest scrap of remaining hope for his total obedience, before Christmas came and went with it their trust in anything but his failure. Trophies on mantelpieces, all for sports and speeches Steve had fumbled his way through, the words he regurgitated anything but his own. 

 

The floral wallpaper is from three summer’s before, just before his mother had another one of her more manic moments and had torn it all apart, replacing it with a clean, almost surgical, white. 

 

There’s an old rug still sitting on the landing, though the soft fabric is drenched with rot and decaying at his feet. 

 

Steve casts a glance over his shoulder, back to Wayne, who gives him a firm nod. An encouragement. Go on . Go in, see him, find him. 

 

The door to his bedroom opens with a soft, wet, creak. 




But there’s no one inside. 




The only solace to Steve is the evidence that even if he isn’t now, there’s no doubt that Eddie was here. 

 

His bed is slept in—covers shifted and crumpled with no attempt to make them back up again. There’s Eddie’s leather jacket strewn across the surface of Steve’s dresser, half torn to shreds where the bats had fought through it to get to flesh. The chain and his belt hang haphazardly on the back of Steve’s chair, which is tucked against the least-used piece of furniture in his room. 

 

The desk. Steve takes a step towards it, features contorted by worry and a sickening dread. He passes opened cans of preservatives, which now hurl with rot and mold, festering on his floor. Stepping over Eddie’s destroyed pair of jeans, Steve stops, taking the chain he’d always had attached to them off of where it’s balanced on his chair, coiling it around his palm. 

 

He squeezes the metal so hard his knuckles go white. 

 

Because in harsh, scrawled letters, carved into the wood of his desk’s surface reads:

 

VECNA. HERE.

 

Eddie’s sharpest ring sitting just below it, scuffed and bent from its handiwork. 

 

“Vecna… that’s the mother fucker who had my Ed killed?” Wayne’s voice growls from behind him, hand touching Steve’s shoulder. 

 

Steve can’t speak. His throat is lined with glass, every forced swallow agony as raw panic throttles him like a hand on the neck of a bottle. He only nods. 

 

Turning on his heel, Wayne storms back out of Steve’s room, gesturing for him to follow. They descend the stairs in a tense hoard, the air between them thick with wrath and dread and a sickly sense that just maybe this was how it was going to go all along. 

 

On his doorstep, Wayne Munson takes Nancy Wheeler’s felonious shotgun, cocks it, and flares up at the sky, rage on his face so hot it comes off of him in waves. “Let’s destroy that son of a bitch,”




 




The Creel House is quiet. 

 

Steve knows, as the bats perch, waiting, quiet—not circling or diving or fighting for flesh and bone, that this is wrong. 

 

It shouldn’t be so quiet.
