Mike’s warnings are sharply tugging at the strings of his heart with every step Steve takes, Wayne rigid and seething at his side. Worry curls away in his chest like a woodlouse, defensive and helpless in the eye of the storm.

 

“It’s too quiet,” Steve says aloud, the bats only following him with their eyes, not even stirring at the sound of his voice. 

 

Wayne grips the shotgun in a fighter’s stance, fury incandescent in his every muscle. “So he’s a bad host. I don’t goddamn care,” And he kicks the stain-glass door open, bustling his way through shoulder-led before it can swing back. 

 

Bile hot in his throat, Steve resists the urge to throw up the last of the tequila sitting raw in his stomach, trailing after him like a kicked puppy. 

 

“I’ll check down here. Go up, kid, holla if he’s there,” Then Wayne turns, taking Nancy’s Makarov out of his pocket, proffering it to Steve. “It’s loaded,” Then he shifts something until it clicks. “That’s the safety off. You run into that fucker before I get there? Shout and shoot, son, and I’ll be there to blow his fuckin’ head off. Y’got that?”

 

Steve wants to shout at Wayne, then beg him to stay close, stay together—but the splenetic fire in his eyes keeps him quiet, pliant. “Okay,” He chokes, drowning in his own unease.

 

Watching Wayne walk away, surveying his surroundings and cautiously studying the corners of the room before continuing on to the next. It’s militant—reminiscent of the veteran he told Steve he was. 

 

It makes Steve feel all the more anxious as he climbs the stairs, not even an inch of the miles of trauma Wayne has experienced and learned from. He doesn’t know how to find the blind spots in a space, seek the nearest exits; not drawn to the miscellaneous items he could make into weapons like a dog to bone. 

 

Steve fumbles his way through the Creel House, lost without his usual headstrong confidence, exhausted and bitterly aware of just how much he’d destroyed himself over the past month. 

 

Eddie isn’t on the first floor. Steve knew he wouldn’t be, and wishes he’d told Wayne as much. If this is a trap—and Steve knows that it is, there’s only one place Eddie will be.

 

Climbing the stairs to the attic, Steve gathers himself on the final one, just before the door, hand shaking where it grips the handle of the Makarov. Just point and shoot. Point, shoot, take Eddie, run. 

 

It’s simple. 

 

But when he finds the last shred of his nerve; pushing the door away from him gently and finds Eddie sprawled out across the floor, limp and far too still, Steve abandons all sense of a plan, throwing himself down to his knees at his side. 

 

His hair is fanned out across the decrepit floorboards, matted and beautifully familiar. It had always drawn Steve’s eyes first; remembers looking at it when Eddie had pressed a bottle to his throat, admiring it despite the circumstances. He’s pale, so white he’s almost blue, flesh cold and stiff under Steve’s desperate touch. 

 

Eddie’s wearing his clothes, Steve’s clothes, the gaudy green-yellow of his letterman jacket stark against the dull tones of the Creel House, hugging Eddie at his wrists and blanketing his marred flesh. 

 

There’s a brutal, jagged line of scarring across his middle where the most fatal of his injuries had been, flesh melded back together again in a mottled display of broken, deformed skin. 

 

He’s beautiful, Steve knows, lacking the strength or will to hate himself for thinking it. He’s so beautiful, but he looks dead. The life that had churned in every aspect of his ferocious being is drained from him, lost in the poisonous air heavy on their skin. 

 

Steve presses his ear to Eddie’s chest, delicate, frantic encouragement toppling from his lips desperately, as if his begging could tempt him to live, breathe.

 

And though Steve isn’t religious, he wonders if he should be, perhaps. Because he counts every single last one of his blessings when Eddie’s heart whines out an unsteady, quiet plea of a beat, pounding away in his hollow chest. 

 

“Eddie?” Steve whispers, chuckling in an act of sheer hysteria, paying no mind to the tears that roll freely down his supple cheeks until they gather beneath him on Eddie’s silent face. “Eddie, hey, Ed,” He splays a hand out across his collarbone, gently shifting him, willing him to respond to his touch, resist or move with him. 

 

Thick eyelashes part, slow and heavy. Big, dark, murky eyes gleam up at him. They’re cloudy until the light of recognition parts through them like crepuscular rays, sharp and bright the way Steve grew fond for. Eddie’s ineffable brilliance, the way he can only ever be vivid, alive, scintillating in his every breath and move is hypnotizing, captivating, and Steve—

 

Steve is surprised when a desperate hand grasps a fistful of his hair by the base of his neck, driving him forwards into a painful clash of lips and teeth. 

 

It’s a bad angle, but Eddie isn’t all that concerned, raising himself in a swift heave of sore limbs and radiant determination to bring Steve to him; against him. Eddie’s hands shift to cup his face, pushing and pulling it with the rhythm of their kiss, the real, violent embrace mingling between them like a blunt sword, strong, yielded, unsheathed. 

 

By the time Steve finds the sense to reciprocate the two of them are tussling around on the uneven floorboards of the Creel’s attic, a tangle of limbs and vehement foolhardiness, two stupid, dumb kids in the midst of hell’s malnourished crevasse. They kiss like they’ve been aching for it, starving for it, lacking the thought nor instinct to know better, question their timing or their place. 

 

But then Eddie comes to, shoves Steve off of him in a sudden spark of consciousness, terror and regret devouring the gentle curvature of his features like a rabid animal. 

 

Steve reaches to comfort him, ready to console; preach of how this was okay, how he wanted this, wanted to kiss him and hold his hand and let him wear his letterman jacket, even if it took Eddie dying and coming to life again in his dreams.

 

But then Eddie presses a firm hand over his mouth, eyes as wide as saucers, sharp with perturbation. “Stevie—no, no-no- no , Stevie you gotta get outta here, man, now,” 

 

Steve wants to tease the use of man after their entanglement, but the sheer aching horror pushing Eddie’s body to the brink of collapse keeps it lodged in his throat. “It’s a trap, Stevie,” Eddie continues, trembling uncontrollably. “I saw it, when he took me, Vecna—you have to go, Steve, come on,”

 

Eddie stands, dragging him with what little strength he had to his feet, Steve stumbling, punch drunk. He wants to reach out to him, continue to confirm that he’s there, he’s real, the hand entwined with his searing into his flesh and reality. 

 

Then comes a strangled yell from beneath them, a fleeting bang of Nancy’s shotgun like a red flare, stark in the darkness around them. A warning. A promise.

 

“Wayne!” Steve cries, startling Eddie beside him, who locks his arm in a vice-grip. 

 

“You brought my uncle, Stevie?!” Eddie barks, voice hoarse and raw from the strain of his grave. 

 

The question posed is quickly answered when a vine punches through the damp wood of the attic’s walls, bringing Wayne with it before tossing him against the structure of the room. His body folds in on itself, curling with pain and shock, startling Eddie to part from Steve’s side, skidding on his knees to where his uncle lies. 

 

Steve turns to join him, to join them both, face stiff with horror as he finds the three deep gashes cutting down the older man’s face, one of his eyes gouged, but he doesn’t get the opportunity. 

 

Vecna ascends from the stairs, hovering above the floors, the fleshy growths stemming from his back keeping him off the ground. 

 

Burnt flesh upon previously scorched flesh is something Steve could have gone his life without seeing. It brings bile to his mouth, lining his tongue in a bitter sheen of illness, the gore of Vecna’s very being a visceral abomination. 

 

Half of his face is melted, one eye missing entirely, his body struggling to hold its own weight under the sheer damage Robin, Nancy and Steve had delivered to his physical form. As he moves, the pulp of his skin shifts in rolls of mangled, mutilated cruor, barely even recognizable as a body at all. 

 

Then he rises, spreading what is left of his limbs, and Steve only realizes what Vecna lifting into that dormant state in this room means when their surroundings dissolve into red. 






It’s all red. The sky, the warm ground beneath him, the distorted reality Vecna has summoned him to an anathema to Steve, the atmosphere writhing with an undeniable, stark air of human suffering. 

 

Chrissy Cunningham’s disfigured corpse is contorted around a sharp, fleshy shard just inches away from him. 

 

It breaks Steve from his disgusted reverie, seizing a cry of horror from his throat so violently he tastes blood, feels it pounding in his head, his ears, his limbs. 

 

Nerves hot in his feet, Steve starts running , despite having nothing to run to, nowhere to go—though it’s futile, only earning him a wet, mangled laugh from Vecna. It’s cruel, the delight he finds as he toys with Steve; captures him by the neck the way the first demobat had, cutting off his panicked gasps for air as the tendril coils around his throat, squeezing. 

 

Steve’s back hits a garish, flesh-like growth, sharp and tall, similar to the one holding Chrissy Cunningham nearby, Patrick McKinney across the way, Fred Benson to his far right. It’s a grave, Steve realizes as the growth leaves him suffocating, pulls frantic tears from his eyes, undeterred by the weak clawing he musters despite his oxygen-starved brain. 

 

Vecna lurches towards him, stopping just inches away—so Steve can smell his scorched flesh, the vine around his throat loosening just enough to force a gag out of him.

 

“Why… so disgusted, Steve?” Vecna’s mutilated claw draws blood from his cheek, cutting where he pretends to caress. “This is your… handiwork. Nancy Wheeler may have… dealt the strongest blows, but it was you, Steve, who threw the first of them,” 

 

If Vecna were capable of smiling, Steve would attribute it to the contorted mess of viscera he’s faced with. “You should be proud,” Comes the rasping whisper, Vecna’s laughter trickling down Steve’s spine like sweat, continuing to sink the length of his claws into the skin of his face, delighting in the way Steve fights to not react. 

 

“If we had the time, Steve, I would… enjoy extending your… suffering,” Vecna soothes, dragging his clawed hand over Steve’s scalp, forcing hot blood to ooze down his head, into his eyes. “But you have… provided me a gift on a… time limit, Steve.”

 

If Steve’s mouth wasn’t painfully dry, he’d spit in Vecna’s fleshy fucking excuse for a face. 

 

Instead, he rasps, writhing in his grip, “What the—fuck are you, even… talking about, you—” Then the tendril tightens again. 

 

Clearly Vecna had no intentions of Steve talking in this confrontation. 

 

“I’m weak, Steve. You and your… friends, you’ve left me like this, I can barely…” Vecna clutches the back of Steve’s head suddenly, scratching a strangled cry of pain out of him. “… move my physical body. And then Eleven, my sister, little... Eleven, she sealed my gates. Trapped me in here, away from… your feeble minds…” 

 

“And then I felt it,” Vecna’s mouth opens, stretching the gore of his remaining face. “Felt you, through the corpse of the boy, the… connection. Those bites you have, Steve,” His claw cuts through Wayne’s carefully applied bandages, sinking into the wounds from the bats. 

 

Steve can barely scream, the pain so unbearable that he almost faints, choking on his own blood. 

 

Vecna seems pleased by this, toying with the broken flesh of his torso. “These bites, once I… reanimated the Munson boy, I could use him… to play with your connection, push his living nightmares into your dreams, reach you through them… filter his consciousness into yours. Use him to lure you here, my final… victim.” 

 

“In my weakness, it turns out that all it took for me to resolve the win you all claim to have taken was…” Vecna’s voice is repulsive, though it’s only a minor contributing factor to the way Steve’s gut turns, twisting inside of him. What he says is like fingers sinking into his viscera, tearing him open from the inside. “…a little stupidity.”

 

“The bites from the bats, their saliva… contain parasites, parasites that live in your blood, Steve. The gates Eleven sealed… believed you to be a creature of the Upside Down, thinking you were stranded in the wrong world. So it opened for you,” Vecna explains, chilling Steve’s blood where it flows, though constricted, through his body. “You opened the gate for me.” 

 

“That one… gate. It is enough for me to reach your world once more. It will be mine,” Vecna gestures viscerally to the corpses strung up like pigs in a slaughterhouse. “ Ours.”

 

“I’m doing you a kindness, Steve Harrington,” Vecna hisses, blood from his mouth spitting against Steve’s face, despite the way he writhes to try and prevent such a fate. “I’m making you my final victim, in all of this. Had you let me have Maxine, this would all be far… less… difficult.”

 

Then his claw unfurls over Steve’s face, the vines sprouting from the mess of Vecna’s flesh snapping taut around the rest of his limbs, pulling them at unnatural angles around the structure behind him. 

 

He sees it, now, sees it all. 

 

Hawkins, divided in four by the gates, fractured, swallowed in flames and tyrannous destruction, those unfortunate to be too close to the origin points dissolved until they’re nothing but mutilated, liquefied flesh. 

 

The fourth and final chime of the grandfather clock; Steve’s fate unleashing what Vecna had failed to do with Max the time before. 

 

His friends, swallowed by the Upside Down’s collision with Hawkins. 

 

Steve’s voice can only muster the air to scream in some distortion of denial, struggling as much as the restriction of Vecna’s vines allowed—little to none. 

 

“You could not accept the death of one, and your guilt and stupidity will lead to the death of the many, Steve Harrington.” Vecna promises. “Perhaps if you had thought, if you had stopped to bring Eleven, I could be defeated. But you are arrogant. You are the pinnacle of human pride, Steve Harrington. You are Prometheus and his flame. In your weakness, I find strength,”

 

Vecna’s clawed hand spreads over Steve’s struggling form, and one vine suddenly whips his leg too far, further than it can go, and there’s a sickening crack. 

 

Steve’s scream leaves him gargling on his own blood, feeling the bone of his leg splinter and shatter, his struggling unavailing in the face of his blatant, imminent death. 

 

Chrissy’s corpse in his peripheral beckons him. Soon, it says to him. He will complete them; complete his collection, bring about the end of the world as it is known to the masses. 

 

“You won’t have to see their suffering, Steve,” Vecna vows, his violent thrashing doing little to deter his words of ‘comfort .’ “But they will all die because of you. Because you could not be satiated. In order to try and save them all, you have led them to their death.” 

 

“He will never forgive you,” Dustin is brought to the forefront of his mind, grief ripping into his features. “She will blame herself.” Robin on her knees, screaming, sobbing. “And what of him? The boy you have sacrificed them all to save?” 

 

Steve sees Eddie, cradling his mutilated corpse, having watched him die just as Chrissy had, helpless. 

 

Grief is a harder drug than the sheer agony of his desecrated leg, high on the vehement distress of what Vecna promises, what he foretells. 

 

“You are what fiction calls a tragic hero, Steve Harrington. It is time for you to die like one,” 

 

Vecna spreads his hand over his face, pulling his head up, his limbs back, forcing his body to the brink of break—





The world of red and viscera explodes from beneath them. 

 

It ripples, reality etching into the hellscape Vecna had scorched into the walls of Steve’s mind, the Creel attic flooding into the harsh scarlet skies. 

 

Steve plummets, feeling his body drop and hit the floor like a ragdoll, useless, wanton. His leg lies beneath him, pointing in an entirely perverted direction, wrong, deviant. 

 

He screams, bloodcurdling anguish setting his every nerve-ending on fire, too painful to find confusion in his freedom from Vecna, not until he finds arms curling around him, moving him despite his sobbing, pleading protests. 

 

Then adrenaline washes over him in a sickly-sweet heat, the warmth of the body he’s pressed against all he can feel, so he swims into it. Drowns in it. 

 

Eddie’s breath is hot against the shell of his ear as he pants and whispers desperate apologies and fleeting comforts. 

 

It’s in his arms that Steve comes to let the scene unravel before him like a carpet, a scroll. 

 

It’s Hopper. 

 

Hopper, holding a machine gun—plastering bullets wantonly into Vecna’s mangled form, flanked by Robin, who seems to have found a passion in the art of a Molotov cocktail, tossing them with a ferocity Steve cannot help but adore. 

 

Wayne stands before Steve and Eddie, a shield, aiming Nancy’s shotgun that he makes his, the gore of his own face returned tenfold as he unloads a fierce sequence of gunfire into what remains of Vecna’s head. 

 

He declares, voice raucous with the passion a father has for his son, with every impact, that it was all for his boy.

 

The artillery ceases, and then comes the final blow.

 

Eleven steps between Robin and Hopper, spreading her hands, those little, delicate hands—raises the disgusting remains of Vecna’s oozing flesh and brings her palms together. 

 

It simply ceases to be. 

 

Perhaps not simply, moreso in a grotesque eruption, blood and gore splattered across the Creel’s attic. 

 

There’s silence, for a beat. 

 

The six of them stand or sit in the aftershock, drenched in the spoils of their win, stunned.

 

Then Eddie giggles, mildly hysterical, “Holy shit. You’re the girl with super powers,”

 

And the moment is broken. 

 

Eleven smiles, licks the blood from her teeth and wipes her nose clean of it too, babbling away about what she knew of Eddie, as if she hadn’t just caused the creature of her nightmares to explode on them all. 

 

Robin startles forwards like a deer on ice, her confidence in battle abandoned for the sake of grabbing Steve in a bone-crushing hug, subsequently reminding him of his mutilated leg. Despite his wail of pain, he forces his arms up, holding her, desperate to dispel the image Vecna had forced into him of her vociferous grief over his death that now would not come. 

 

He holds her close, sobbing into the space between her shoulder and neck a series of pain-drunk apologies, ones she hushes, trying to speak over him to offer her own. 

 

Over her shoulder he sees Hopper approach Wayne, clap him on the shoulder in his gruff way, likely trading brusque, coarse compliments over their mutual destruction.

 

And then Eddie returns to Steve’s side; smile wry and faintly affectionate, though it’s tainted with exhaustion and a little guilt. 

 

Robin releases him, though one of her arms stays taut against his back, collapsing against his side while Eddie kneels at his other. 

 

“I could punch you, Stevie, for making me see that shit again,” Eddie says earnestly, reaching to caress the soft skin of his cheek, the rough palm of his hand a welcome comfort. “Don’t do that ever again. Never fucking ever, you hear me, fuckwit?”

 

Steve can feel Robin nodding along enthusiastically in a passionate agreement, jittering beside him. 

 

“I,” Steve’s voice cracks, startling himself. Adrenaline keeps his brain pleasantly foggy, his vision blurry and light around the edges. “I won’t. Promise,” He’s not entirely sure what he’s promising to Eddie, but he knows it could be just about anything and he wouldn’t mind all that much. 

 

Maybe he says that aloud, because Eddie laughs, soft, careful, and brings that hand on his face up to tangle in his hair, pushing Steve’s head forwards to kiss him. 

 

It’s a nice kiss. A very nice kiss, and though part of Steve is highly aware of Robin sitting next to him, most of Steve is just happy to be kissed by Eddie in the midst of his delightful adrenaline high and the beginnings of his body going into shock. 

 

Unbeknownst to him, however, Eddie uses his other hand to signal Eleven with a thumbs-up.

 

And then he’s snatched from the pleasant numbness of adrenaline when the girl spreads her hand and forcefully snaps the bone in his leg back into its original direction. 

 

It seems everyone was in on it—Steve’s proceeding shriek of pain is muffled by the sleeve of his own letterman jacket promptly stuffed into his mouth by Eddie, his arms pinned by Robin so he can’t thrash. Wayne and Hopper seem unperturbed, though Eleven appears apologetic, there’s no regret on her face. 

 

“Sorry, Stevie,” Eddie presses a kiss to his temple, removing the material gag from Steve’s mouth to allow him to pant out the pain, face creased with guilt and an amused exhaustion. “If we dragged you back home with your leg like that, they’d probably chop it off in Hawkins hospital.”

 

Robin gives his hand a squeeze. “Hawkins—they love amputation, actually, and it would be so sad because you’ve always said you have nice legs so it would be a tragedy, really, this is uh, a necessary evil, as they say, and it’ll stop hurting when you pass out, because you definitely look like you’re about to pass out, Steve, but take this as like—karma for, for just running off into the Upside Down without us,”

 

“She’s right,” Hopper crouches down by Steve, ignoring his whimpers when he uses Nancy’s shotgun as a splint for his leg, giving him a look. “Mike wanted me to tell you he waited ten minutes, not twenty. And you’re goddamn lucky he did kid. Those ten minutes saved your life.” 

 

Eleven nods along at her father’s words, arms folded tight across her chest. “Friends do not do things alone, Steve. We are your friends.”

 

If Steve wasn’t already being pulled down into the tempting promise of unconsciousness as Robin predicted, he’d be groveling away—but all he can muster for now is a sleepy nod to their scolding, head rolling back to rest against Eddie’s chest. 

 

As darkness swims over his vision in droves, he hears Wayne move to offer Hopper a hand, the other giving Steve’s shoulder a careful squeeze. That squeeze says you did good, kid. That squeeze promises that it’ll be alright—they’ll take it from here. 

 

“Let’s get our boys home, Jim,”









Hawkins adjusts to not only their police chief returning from the dead, but now the town pariah, too.

 

Free to roam the streets, the police force is quick to remind everyone that Eddie Munson was cleared of all involvement, quick to spread the news of Henry Creel, and to set their government-assigned story straight. 

 

Eddie Munson enjoys the most of his newfound freedom and life, bothering Steve Harrington. 





 

 

Steve’s recovery is slow, arduous. Physical therapy becomes his worst enemy, his leg refusing to move like it should, like it had done before. He’s frustrated a lot of the time, exhausted the rest of it—but when he has to relearn how to walk, Eddie is always there to hold his hand. 

 

His presence is a comfort, a constant. 

 

He’s not the only one, either. 

 

Where Steve’s family don’t come at all, Wayne Munson seems to dedicate himself to filling their gaps, frequently appearing in the hospital room to entertain Steve and his nephew with a lecture or three. He’s got a patch for his missing eye, Eddie’s pirate jokes insufferable but also a part of that consistency about him Steve can’t help but adore. 

 

The Munsons come together with Dustin to form a strange family unit, Claudia Henderson even visiting to deliver them all homemade food to make up for the atrocities of Hawkins’ hospital meals. 

 

(Steve’s also half convinced that it eventually becomes an excuse for her to see Wayne. He’s not all that offended.)

 

Dustin was another piece in the puzzle of Steve’s slow journey to recovery, slotting in place like they’d never parted at all. He’d been waiting for them in the Munson trailer, held back from following them into the Upside Down only by a very firm Joyce Byers. 

 

Steve had witnessed the reunion of Eddie and Dustin in one of his passing moments of consciousness, the brotherhood between them no longer stirring sickly, bitter jealousy in him. No, when Dustin and Eddie make up for their lost time these days through DnD, disastrous science projects and a determination to read the entirety of Lord of the Rings to Steve in his hospital bed—all he can feel is hopelessly fond. 

 

His other most frequent visitors are two people he’d deem the most unlikely— Max and Mike. 

 

His apology to Max for what was undeniably a reliance on alcohol all-too-familiar to her had left them both in tears, resulting in a pact to never speak of it when the redhead had clambered onto the bed to give Steve a proper hug. 

 

Mike’s visits were coloured by I-told-you-so’s and the cool air of serious relief he exuded, eventually working up to telling Steve that even if he was a total moron, he was glad that at least he had the gall to be stupid and alive. It was a bridge, something in their bond finally clicking into place the way it had with the other kids.

 

The other kids—Lucas, Jesus. Steve loved that kid, loved his patience when Steve could finally get on his feet again, when he’d come with him every morning to the basketball court. Make sure Steve kept his leg moving, even though he was slow and totally shit at the game now, Lucas never rubbed his face in it. He had the patience of a saint, and could often be the only reason Steve had to force himself out of bed in the morning in the latter half of his recovery. 

 

Will was still painfully shy, but when Jonathan would come for his regularly scheduled welfare-checks, he’d tag along, find something exciting to chatter away about to take Steve’s mind off of everything else. 

 

It was nice—nice enough that he eventually wore him down, getting Steve to agree to let him make a character sheet for an upcoming campaign of his. Will could tell he had no idea what any of it meant, but was never mean about it. 

 

El wasn’t as common company as the others, at least not on her own—she would be with Hopper or the Party as a whole. But when she did come to see Steve, she’d bring pre-microwaved eggos, and would use her powers to take the pressure off of his leg despite his assurances that she really didn’t have to. 

 

Nancy was furious with him, ardently refusing to see him for the first month of his hospital stay—but Robin assured him that she’d visit when he was asleep anyway, despite his breaking and entering. The two of them were close, now, almost suspiciously so—but when Jonathan didn’t seem all that upset about the girls holding hands all the time, Steve decided the topic was best left to be broached by someone other than him. 

 

(Nancy does, in the end. Tells him he can’t be mad about his ex dating his best friend, jokingly claims it to be revenge for stealing her guns. Steve promises he doesn’t mind, but gives her the shovel talk over Robin for the sake of it.) 

 

His recovery wasn’t the only one happening, anyway, not after the complications that came with being taken back from the grave. To Hawkins hospital, Eddie is a total enigma, one the lab has to fork out several thousand of hush money to fund his treatment. 

 

Eddie claims that actually most of both of their recovery was funded by him, or occasionally Argyle. The running joke was that weed was the one true healer—ironically, it did actually help Steve with the chronic pain in his leg, but he didn’t need that as an excuse. Not with an ex-drug dealer for a boyfriend. 

 

Boyfriend. What a word—a word Steve couldn’t stop using. It was addictive, and the only person who could understand his giddiness was his better half, Robin, utterly obsessed with the fact that Steve’s stupidity had helped push her to win Nancy Wheeler as a girlfriend. 

 

(“It helped that you were a shitty boyfriend. You really lowered her standards.”)

 

(“Anything for you, Robin.”)

 

She was living her own love story, one Steve could absolutely understand, having lived it in another life himself. It didn’t mean that he wanted to hear every extended ramble about Nancy’s every minor quirk and breath taken at their shifts at Family Video, but thankfully in his time at the hospital, Keith had been bribed into taking on another employee.

 

That being one Eddie Munson. 

 

Robin had promised that the ladies loved a bad boy, and a mysterious one, too. The Steve Eddie combination once discharged from the loving embrace of Hawkins hospital would be unmatched. 

 

Mostly Eddie’s addition to Family Video meant there was someone to sort the horror films properly, someone to go with Steve to the back room and make sure he definitely wasn’t all that scared. Eddie became an integral part of their work life, the trio to end all duos, and actually seemed to enjoy working there. 

 

So back when the hospital declared Steve sufficiently healed enough to be discharged permanently from their physical therapy program—he really shouldn’t have been surprised when Wayne had Eddie’s van parked in the lot, waiting with bags of Steve’s stuff to take back to the trailer park.

 

They’d pooled together their savings from work to buy another—parked it beside the one the government had reluctantly replaced. No gate in the ceiling, fresh, new. Comfortably cramped. 

 

Eddie frequented both trailers, one for Wayne and the other in Steve’s name—he was happy to frolick between both, though typically ended up curled around Steve come nighttime, sleeping tangled up with him in a gangly pile of limbs. 

 

Being opposite Max was nice, too. Because if her mom ever had more of a troubled evening, she’d take the pullout couch in Steve’s living space, or knock on his window if she had a nightmare. 

 

A lot of time was spent, Eddie, Max and Steve, sat in the grass stargazing in the odd hours of the morning when Vecna’s transgressions kept them wide-awake. 

 

On the worst nights they’d sleep there, sprawled out in the grass—woken up by Wayne returning from his night shift, or Max’s mom on her way to her workplace. 

 

But mostly the best thing about living in the trailer park was Eddie. Alive, vibrant, insane. Every morning Steve woke up and wanted to say a thousand prayers to whatever force had pushed him into his life through tragedy and let them come out of it relatively okay. 

 

Every time Steve couldn’t move his leg for the stiffness, the agony in his joints, Eddie would sweep him off his feet and remind him. He’d be there and Steve wouldn’t feel it anymore, the sheer relief of Eddie being with him, Eddie not just his one failure—it was intoxicating. Overwhelming in the best kind of way. 

 

It brings them to now, lying on the soft space of their bed, one hand casting through Eddie’s hair while he listens to the mixtape made for him—Steve’s mixtape that Eddie would’ve played to save him from Vecna. 

 

“There’s a shitton of Tears for Fears on there, Stevie, I hope you know just how much of my sanity I sacrificed making it,” Eddie teases, tracing the shape of Steve’s nose with his fingertip. 

 

Steve’s smile is lopsided on his face, sloppy in his fondness. “You’re so goddamn whiny. It’s not my fault your taste is shit,”

 

“Yeah? My taste is shit?” Eddie jostles Steve lightly, pointedly raising his eyebrows when he rolls him onto his back. 

 

Scoffing, Steve realizes just how much he walked into that one. “You’re lucky I love you, asshole,”

 

“Yeah? Am I?” Eddie’s nose scrunches, hands coming up to squish Steve’s face. “I think I’ll find you’re the one lucky I love you. I had to sit through your preppy pop shit to make that, you know. Agony. But I love you and your flaws,” 

 

They kiss, then, even at their odd angle—something common between them. They make strange circumstances work, adaptability entirely their thing. 

 

(Especially considering their first kiss had been incredibly poorly timed, but nonetheless.) 

 

It’s sweet, tender in the setting summer-autumn sun as it streams in through their bedroom window, warm on their faces, their tangling bodies. They toss and turn until they fit together just how they like, comfortable for Steve’s leg, suitable for the way Eddie likes to keep moving. It’s a learned practice, an unspoken language, though it can often involve more than one tongue. 

 

The two of them steal moments like this, moments that make the pain and the trauma worth it, reinforce the ideal that Vecna tried to use to scorn Steve.

 

He would’ve sacrificed any part of him to save Eddie. The weight of the world couldn’t amount to the weight in his arms, now, the weight of him on his chest. Steve wakes up and breathes him in, goes through the motions of their life, the one they forge together, and knows that though they may never heal, at least their suffering forged a relentless good.

 

Then again, it also created endless interruptions.

 

“Ew, gross,” Comes the vindicated voice of Max, peering through their open trailer window. “Stop making out, Dustin’s already started eating dinner,”

 

That gets Eddie’s attention, rolling off of Steve unceremoniously. “That total shitbag!” He declares, vaulting out of the window and stumbling across the grass to get to Wayne’s trailer. 

 

“Are you coming?” Max snipes back at Steve, hands on her hips. 

 

Chuckling to himself, Steve pads his way through to the door of his trailer, opening it up as opposed to following Eddie’s more flexible route. “Yeah, yeah, keep your hat on, Max, if Dustin eats all the potatoes again I promise you Eddie won’t let his character live through his next campaign,”

 

“A fate worse than actual death,” Max deadpans, linking her arm with Steve’s as they walk across the way together. 

 

They step into Wayne’s trailer, Max abandoning him to fling herself towards the selection of food on the table. Claudia Henderson is attempting to negotiate a truce between her son and Eddie, who seems vindicated by the large portion of casserole Dustin has taken from the bowl. Wayne is watching, amused, though using the distraction as a means of taking more of his share in the red meats of the food, fixing Steve an eyebrow raise, as if daring him to challenge his authority. 

 

Steve doesn’t. He just smiles, shaking his head fondly before pulling up a chair—glad to all heavens that this is how he ended up spending his summer. 

 

(And many more summers to come, too.)
